reviewText:
Pros: If you're an old-timer longing for the good old days of min-maxing stats/skills for a party (and you don't play JRPGs for various reasons), this will be the game for you. Your gameplay rewards will mostly come from seeing your carefully-planned party composition hit its stride around the mid-levels, when your bladesinger has enough stats to chunk mobs for big satisfying criticals. This game will mostly appeal to RPG fans born in the very early 80s or older, since it's a throwback to the Xeen/Terra style of gameplay. It includes all the quirks of those previous games such as tile movement, turn-based combat, random stat-increasing barrels and high-level party-oneshotting dragons in the midst of a lowly bandits and wolves. Full shameless nostalgia.


Cons: It's still buggy. Your party can get stuck around teleporters, music and ambient sounds can loop forever, and some events don't trigger. Also many parts are under-developed. Armor system is underbaked (you can finish the game with your warrior wearing cloth), a couple spells are placeholders (eg liquid membrane), some classes are more fleshed out than others, tanking is near-useless, there is an overdependence on specific spells (eg Celestial Armor, Burning Determination and Whispering Secrets) which make or break your game.

reviewText:
I've been a Might and Magic fan since the golden days. My personal favorite being Might and Magic 6: The Mandate of Heaven. This game is more of a take of the earlier Might and Magic games (Clouds / Darkside of Xeen). Although it pays homage to Might and Magic through gameplay, most of the familiarity ends there. That's not to say, however, that I didn't really enjoy this game.

Combat is turn-based. Character customization leaves something to be desired. The classes are unbalanced and vaguely described, you won't really know what the classes are capable of until much later in the game; and by then it's too late and you'll be stuck with a couple of characters that are far less capable/effective as others, so I recommend doing some google-research on the class-combos before going all in.

If you have never tried the Legend of Grimrock series, I would buy those first, as I think they offer a better tribute to the genre.

It's a fun throwback to the grid-system, dungeon crawler RPG. If you can get it on sale and you're an oldschool PCRPG'er, then I would recommend this game to you.

reviewText:
I had been a massive fan of the Might & Magic franchise when I was younger, and had been disappointed by the Might & Magic 9. After hearing that they were going to try and create M&M 10 with a retro feel I was hoping that they would rekindle some of the spark that M&M 1 – M&M 8 had.

Unfortunately, this had been another disappointment due to poor and confusing combat/spell systems, character development that is quite unforgiving and leaves me feeling that choice is an illusion and to get anywhere in the game you need a specific build of character.

I felt the limiting of classes to race and the extremely limited choice in character appearance was unnecessary and made the options you had to build a unique character even more obvious. The story telling had been weak and had not been focused on delivering short, clear and easy to follow story line.

I struggle to find any saving graces for the series, except the desire to continue the series. In conclusion I wouldn’t recommend this game to any fan of the original Might & Magic series.

reviewText:
I effing love turn-based RPGs. I also love any game where I can create my own party and try to make their unique skills work together into a harmonious vision. Also I love exploration. Also dungeon-crawling, especially the type that rewards searching walls and floors for traps and other dangerous things.

Might and Magic X - Legacy contains all those things.

Don't buy it.

It's like everything I like about the genre has been taken, then subverted to make it ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

There is a turn-based system, but the turn-based movement ceases to work when in combat. There is no maneuvering once enemies are in melee range. You can never take a tactical withdrawl or move to bottleneck your foes. There is no party formation, so your characters stand in a line up front. This is not Grimrock, where the people at the back of your party are mostly vulnerable to attacks from foes that have specifically flanked you. This is Might and Magic, where your unarmored mages hurl themselves in front of every stray arrow or blade they can find, as though their torso posessed by the ghost of a weapon collector.

You can, however, make your own party. I meticulously used all four available races (Orc, Human, Dwarf and Elf) to make what I thought was a balanced party that would have unique skills that complemented each other. A true adventuring party, if you will. It turns out what I wanted basically didn't matter, because the level of party customization in the game is basically like paint over a piece of cardboard. There are 'classes', but they just determine how far your skills can advance, which has no bearing on the early game. They have 'advanced classes' that are unlocked at some point, but just one per class, so really it's just the inevitable progression of your class' skills. No class starts with a special ability that makes it unique. Only advanced classes get those. So your Mercenary (a might-based fighter) that's dabbling in Air Magic is -just as good at it- as the fully-specialized Freemage. Wait, you say that the Freemage is more heavily invested in the Magic attribute and is better with magic? Yeah, 8% better at the start. Hot stuff. That might increase by a whole 8% per level, too! All the while you're completely neglecting your mage's ability to stay alive by investing in Vitality or Perception, so really it's closer to 2% per level.

Basically your meticulously planned party is going to be ineffective, because the game doesn't really want you to experiment with the parts of the skill system that you like. Want to invest in Warfare (a fighter's equivalent to casting spells) and have a battlefield commander? ♥♥♥♥ you. Now your fighter can't hit anything to save his life, and you need to land your Challenge attacks to draw the attention of enemies, who will then proceed to mangle your fighter that didn't invest heavily in their armor skills.

Basically there are no good decisions, and that seems to be how the game likes it.

Monster fighting is tiresome. The earliest quests have you dealing with spiders that poison you with their basic attacks. Poison never goes away without a (fairly expensive) antidote or specific spell that nobody can start with. So any of your characters that get poisoned by this frequent attack will inevitably go 'unconscious' without immediate medical attention. Being unconscious doesn't clear the poison. The poison is eternal. My Dwarf Defender didn't recover from poison after resting for twenty-four hours. Or ever. Not without help. So 'camping' to tend to your wounds just refills your health bars and then you watch them rapidly deteriorate from the poison that never disappeared. It takes about six 'steps' in game for people to keel over dead after getting up from their nap.

What.

Monsters don't get any better. Naga in the second dungeon (the first after the 'tutorial' with the spiders) dual-wield and attack twice per turn, gaining more damage if they hit with the first swing. They regularly one-hit your spellcasters and cannot be provoked into attacking anyone wearing armor without spamming 'challenge' attempts, which costs mana and rarely lands. Naga priestesses spam ice spells just as strong as the party's, but don't suffer from mana conservation. Everything crits. You guzzle mana and health potions every three rounds. I don't want to say 'unrealistic' when talking about my fantasy dungeon crawlers, but my god...

I don't even...

I hate to compare this game to Grimrock (which was brilliant), because it doesn't feel fair. Grimrock was a labor of love for people that love this genre. Legacy was a kick in the nuts trying to cash in on nostalgia with a low price tag and promises it doesn't deliver on. Exploring dungeons doesn't have player attentiveness rewarded by secret passages and vast loot. Instead, your characters bark out their discovery of things, waiting for you to mash your face against every nearby wall until something glows and you open a new passage with the spacebar.

Riveting.

Traps are mandatory. Often they just sit on a required pathway, and almost always just spawn more monsters. Usually in flanking positions. Even if you detect a trap your only choice is to mash your face into it, or, in rare circumstances, walk around the otherwise empty room.

Loot is a mess of +2 to damage and +5 to some nebulous resistence stats. It's also completely random and there's no such thing as farming, so if the wrong loot drops for your party...♥♥♥♥ you. I guess you can reload, save-scumming for better loot, but is that something we really want to encourage?

I've been told the game opens up, both in terms of exploration and tactics, but after my first party (which I was a fool to put on the harder of the two difficulties, which made it nearly unplayable) couldn't pass the second dungeon, I don't think I'm going to make it there. My second party has the exact same problem in the exact same dungeon, you see. On the 'much easier' difficulty.

Developers and veterans will probably giggle because someone can't handle their hardcore game. Their perogative. I'm still not going to reccomend this steaming mess to anyone.

Slow, unsatisfying, tiresome. Avoid it.

reviewText:
I didn't play the other MM games so I can't compare it to previous MM titles. Only 22 hrs in but I sat down at midnight Friday and now I HAVE to quit playing because of work tomorrow (Mon). I slept a little somewhere in there but ate my meals at the computer and only got up to pee. My point is....I was gone... totaly engrosed in this world. I guess you can say I like it. :)
To be honest, I did try it many, many moons ago, but this time I gave it a REAL fair shot and now I'm hooked.
Will others like it? Dunno. I see some reviews which are bad, but all of those reviews are from peeps with little time in the game. That was me the first time. But now, ... I LOVE THIS GAME!!....and here's why:

Animations         superior
Tactics                great if you prepare correctly, bothersome if you try to spend valuable gold for an additional +2.....
World                  interesting ... readings in lore are short ...which can be a good thing in a crpg.
Fun                      it's got that feeling" I don't know. theres a French term for it but my French is limited to Fries and toast.
Atmosphere        Really fantastic...banging sounds in dungeons
hoursPlayed: sea.......\nMusic                   Pretty good....its no Hans Zimmer

reviewText:
If you can get past the roughness of the visuals (texture resolutions seem to be aimed for sub 1080p monitors, gui doesn't scale so you have massive texts and buttons on big monitors, some cheap particle spell effects) you can find one enjoyable Dungeon Master -like game. Nice locations, interesting foes, pretty decent combat and character mechanics.

One thing they seriously need to adjust / change is how poison works. There are way too many dungeons with poison attack enemies and getting poisoned without potions means death because resting doesn't really heal you from it and you don't have cure spells in the beginning. Antidote potions were easy to come by in the first dungeon as the enemies occasionally dropped them, but in later dungeon you have ranged poison enemies (that also cause poison with melee) and no source of anything to cure it with. A bit frustrating.

edit: Apparently you can get cure poison spell with novice level earth magic, but point still stands that poison is really annoying and way too frequent effect in the beginning.

I do recommend this game though! Slow first hour, but gets really nice afterwards.

reviewText:
I've had a good few hours with game.  No bugs so far.  Running smooth enough. I had a bit of lag at a bridge outside but no where else.
Few thingts are different from the older games .  You level on the spot instead of training for example
Combat is faster then early access from what I can tell from posts on the forum(was deemed to slow).
I am playing in warrior mode; not finding it too hard so far, playing with default party..  Button mashing will just get you killed.   You have to put some thought into combat.  you can blow enemy back with one char then root it with other for example witch I found cool.

You get out into open world pretty fast and no restrictions as where you can go apart from places were you need water walking etc.  Similar to earlier games.

Some items have exact same name but different stats wich can be annoying slightly.
Can see enemies but can't just attack em, got to get close enough to trigger battle.  I presume this is intentional.
Map could be a bit better so don't have to hover over everything to see whats there; adding note didn't help still had to hover over icons.
I see these as minor gripes and don't really take away from my enjoyment.

I am glad I purchased game so far and would recommend if you're into the older titles and games like legend of Grimlock, Realms of Arkania remake (it is in a very playable state after many patches)
I got a good feeling that I am going to enjoy this and was money well spent so far.

Update:
Had to strart again because enemies don't respawn and you can run out of money quite easily.
In the first act I found that you can't just do quests in any order because you get wasted.  I had done all outside mobs except for w*****  and got to boss in tower.  I just can't survive long enough because I used me potions up and no way to get gold.  So I can't last it out using hp regen.  Thats the only mob left in act one plus 2 wraiths.  Can't do them either cause need something that can't afford.
I still recommend game but you can quite easily make wrong choices that can basically make it game over.  Respawning enemies would give the option to grind a bit if you did not chose the skills, spells to succeed.

I get were people are coming from when they say it feels like its a bit on rails.  Hope act 2 dosen't give me same feeling.  This is in warrior mode default party.  Don't wanrt to play adventurer mode because people say too easy; can just button mash.

Update: With better planning I managed to finish act 1 with no problems at all; with default party on warrior mode.  I've managed to cross the bridge.  Enjoying myself a lot more second time round.  Now I have a better idea of howto make sure I don't end up getting stuffed because I didn't get some must have spells.  I rest now instead of drinking potions during fights.

reviewText:
Review written : 28. January 2014 (5 days after release -expect some bugs to get fixed later on)
will add to the review after the release of the first dlc

Allrighty, first things first, for those that are curious : this game is not worth the money, it was a massive disappointment for me after spending years waiting for a new might and magic and overall it just feels like a downgraded version of legend of grimrock - the only upgrade being the price of the game - i will go into details below.
Also note that you have to use Uplay to start MMX

---General Stuff---

Settings used : 1600x900 windowed, everything set to high

- Game crashes a lot, for me it averaged around 1 crash per hour, sometimes crashing more frequently, sometimes less, depending on where you are in the game. (crashes more frequently at night)
- Huge FPS drops, even bigger at nighttime or when using teleporters. MMX goes down to like 1-5 FPS and apparently tries to reload all the trees and other objects in front of you, there are tons of people with that problem in the Ubisoft forums, so it is related to the game, not computer specs (my computer can handle all new games anyways)
- Annoying loading times, when loading savegames or quickloading. Can take up to 30 seconds when transitioning in and out of dungeons. (this is most fun when you are trying to navigate the optional dungeon with instant kill traps, leading to a quickload if you make a wrong move)

These three points alone ruined the game for me, because it feels like trying to play skyrim on a pentium 3.
But let's also take a look at some of the games Key Features" from the store page.

Open world
Travel through stunning environments
date: choose which region you want to explore first but be careful
recommended: danger is never far off.\n- This is pretty misleading. Most areas are sealed off at the start and have to be opened with quest items from main quests. for example you can only access around 20% of the world before completing Act 1

reviewText:
This game certainly isn't for everyone but it isn't just for old school rpg fans either. While the game will be a solid nostalgia rush for any fans of the early M&M and 90's Western RPGs, it still stands on its own feet well and doesn't need that nostalgia to be an enjoyable title.

If you haven't played a game like it before then the grid based movement and the first person turn based combat will be quite jarring but trust me, after a few hours of playing it'll become second nature and you'll be loving it. It's a title that does take a bit of getting into to, and it's pretty difficult [the first boss on the lower difficulty is quite likely to kill you and the game isn't forgiving about it] but if you're an rpg fan then I'd highly recommend this.

I'm also incredibly excited to see this type of game making a return in some form, so here's to hoping that M&M XI followins in the footsteps of M&M6-8!!

reviewText:
While a rather massive lore and gameplay departure from the old Might and Magic games, this is still a pretty fun and engaging game. I would watch out for bugs, as there are a few little ones that crop up here and there, mostly graphics related though. It has a good deal of flaws, but it also, like any game, has a good deal of good things about it.

If anyone here is interested in the HoMM series, particularly the sixth one, this game provides some interesting perspective on it.

There are some irritations like a penchant for throwing ambushes at you all the time. In that respect, I would probably recommend easy mode over the hardmode that is available. I played it on hard, and rather than rewarding, it is more of a chore.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Spotty textures, limited descriptions, annoying glitches... and yet something about Might and Magic X: Legacy is so very, very Awesome.

Thanks to Legend of Grimrock (a game I also recommend and IMHO better than this), there has been a resurgance of grid-based dungeon crawlers. Legacy follows suit and provides hours of singleplayer entertainment that many RPG fans will likely enjoy. While anyone trying out grid-based rpgs first time should try the cheaper and more polished Grimrock first, Legacy will scratch that RPG itch whenever it comes up. If its too much for you now, save it to your wishlist for a future sale.

Legacy's combat and character management is where the game really shines. Many of the toughest boss fights are challenging, unique and provide a great sense of accomplishment after bringing them down. You might find yourself reloading a save once or twice as you figure out a bosses mechanics. Even the common enemies can't be taken down with just basic attacks and rightfully punishes players who underestimate their foe. Large variety in classes and skills makes every character level up feel meaningful and potent as you mold your party into your own. You'll find yourself using nearly every skill you acquire, from minor spells like Light Orb or Fire Ward to the warfare skills of your melee classes to powerful grandmaster spells like Thunderstorm. The default party offers a great balance to different playstyles, but there are so many different class/racial combinations its worth building your own unique party, especially if you plan to only make one playthrough.

Different scenery and enemies throughout the game offers much needed variety, which the Legend of Grimrock lacks. Dungeons are engaging, fun and filled with secrets; which are found with a perception check rather than the players own cunning and discovery. That said, the developers have wisely taken many of the games puzzles and placed them in mysterious crypts" dotted around the map
date: rather than amongst the major quests which could serve to only slow the pacing. Even than
recommended: the crypts offer excellent items worth trying to get
hoursPlayed: but by no means necessary to complete the game. Storyline is your typical fanasty affair with an unseen villian who needs stopping
voteText: but interesting enough to provide some entertainment.\n\nFantastic RPG specific qualities aside

column17: though I haven't run into them myself.\n\nMany of the quests also lack enough description which might leave you trying to figure out what exactly your looking for. World map is also painfully simple

You'll also need a pen or pencil once or twice as your party seems to have none of their own for a couple critical details.\n\nMight and Magic: Legacy X is a fun addition to grid-based RPGs and I felt was worth the $25

reviewText:
Review of Might and Magic X: Legacy

What must first be said is that this is not going to be your average run of the mill rpg, the designers of this game has made it a somewhat old-school type game, and what that means is that the game will not hold your hand and lead you through it. This can be surprising and frustrating as you sometimes wander around aimlessly, having possibly missed some small detail that means that you are now on the wrong path. Since the name of the game is indeed 'Legacy', maybe we should have come to expect this and be completely ok with it, but I think it still needs to be said that the lack of descriptions of where to go in this game can be a problem. This problem can be more or less immediately rectified however, as long as you are willing to alt tab from the game to google, which is something that I personally ended up doing multiple times, even though I would consider myself somewhat of a veteran gamer.

The main plot of the game is convoluted, as it should be (follows the traditions of the older games), and there is a relatively little emphasis on story, as it should be. Most of what you do in the game is exploring, and fighting. Many npc's however have the option to spill some minor 'gossip' to the player, which is most of the time just random bits of lore of the gameworld. Scattered throughout the world is also many books, which holds a lot of lore of the world, if this is your thing.

The characters your party is comprised of are created manually by the player (unless you insist on letting the computer do it for you), and they all have lots of attribute points and skills that needs to be allocated. There is a nice range of depth to the character building in this game, as the 12 classes available all have different levels of potential with different skills. The mage characters can usually level up certain magic skills to the highest level (grandmaster), but also has the potential of leveling up certain weapon skills, armor skills, and passive defense skills. This well functioning skill system works together with your attribute system to give the player quite a lot of customization options for his party. It essentially *succeeds* in making the player feel like they are the one who created this team, as opposed to having few options and feeling like you are playing a non-rpg. The games skill and attribute system is sufficient, and well expected as it follows the traditions of the older Might and Magic titles. But that doesn't mean that it is fresh, or innovative. It also isn't balanced very well. The armor skills are shown to be very lackluster once you understand the games mechanics for example.

The game is entirely grid based. This is a design choice that has huge implications for gameplay, but it is an intrinsic part of the experience, and there is nothing to be done about it now. The entire game is built around this, and as such the environments of the game has the probability of looking quite odd and unrealistic, if you compare it to Skyrim for example. The world is also quite small, it would only take about 3 minutes to run through the length of the entire overworld map (once you have killed all the enemies, and opened everything). This is not because the game is small or short, but because of how compressed everything is, but this is a good thing most of the time, as otherwise there would have been an enormous amount of walking for you - that's a promise. The way the dungeons are built in this game screams 'gameplay' over 'realism', and thankfully so. Maybe it doesn't make any sense that the governor of a peninsula is living in a castle that effectively looks like a labyrinth? But it makes for fun adventuring, so I am pleased.

The main focus of the game could be said to be fighting, and fighting is done in a turn based tactical manner. You get to make one action with each of your characters during your turn, such as casting spells or attacking with weapons, (but this hardly has to be said I hope). You will encounter many enemies that will give you a run for your money, and I hope you will welcome the challenge. There has been a couple of posts both on Steam and on Ubisofts forum of players complaining about not being able to progress because their party is too weak. There is the hypothetical possibility that you might gimp your characters to the point of not being able to continue. But one must understand that this is a necessity in a game if you want freedom for the player to design their own party in meaningful ways, and still pose a challenge.

Finally, the game is produced by Ubisoft and requires Uplay to play, which can be a detriment, as most people don't want Uplay to clog up their computer as the millionth gamehub service" program. Having popups that try to direct you to Youtube every time you exit the game is hardly a plus either
date: but that's something that Ubisoft thinks is a cool thing.\n\nScore is a whopping 85/100 for me personally. It's the perfect blend between rpg and strategy
recommended: and will probably leave you with a feeling of satisfaction if you are a min-maxing geek like myself. But you have to look past some of the things mentioned earlier in my text to get the most out of it."

reviewText:
So, now that the game is in full, lets get down to the ♥♥♥♥ and grits of the game.  What is wrong with it? And what is right with it?  Well.. currently, I am engaging in a full playthrough.  In my first 30 minutes, I discovered that the game seems to require MUCH more system resources than it should for the type of game you are playing.  The game also seems to take several steps BACKWARDS!! in regards to the progress that has been made in the dungeon Crawler genre of games.  It makes a sort of Dated, modern take on a familiar genre that has had leaps and bounds of progress made, 10 years ago.

It may get better later... but currently, it clearely shows dated mechanics that I would have expected a company like Ubisoft to invest in improving (IE full voice overs, a fully explorable world) if they actually believed in the project.

Currently, SOME of the main quest givers actually speak, and the game moves in a old school (and I mean super old school) grid method which is dated even for the 90s.  The game runs poorly which is honestly unforgiveable.  And last but not least, it just seems limiting in regards to the way you make your party.  That last one is a minor gripe, but I am in a nit picky mood at the time of this review.

So what does the game do right?  Well, currently it seems very balanced, and the game is full of lore if you do not mind reading.  The story ties in with a familiar world (thus far) if you have been paying attention to the previous games in the series, and even comes with several nods to those games.  It isn't a terrible game, it could have been much worse, and the game is most certainly playable.  It seems balanced (at the time of the review) and I have yet to encounter a real problem space that I simply could not finish.  I will complain though, that I have yet to discover a way to flee a combat.  Which I find to be in poor taste... there is simply no way I have found to disengage from a fight once something closes the distance etoo you.  So I would suggest to be VERY careful.  Makes you think actually, which is a good thing in a manner of speaking.  Unfortunately, some fights you will not know you can't deal with until you start the fight, so save often.

is the game worth getting?  Currently, I am totally torn.  The super fan of this genre is willing to accept even a mediocre title, and invest.  The game itself is not above 30 dollars in charge, but at the same time I am torn to say that you should wait till it goes on sale before picking it up.  Why get a game from a big company, when you can get a great game from a smaller indie company... (go get legend of Grimmrock)  If you are a true blue fan of might and magic, and you want another dungeon crawl to add to your list, then by all means, the game is not unplayably bad.  But just understand, that you are supporting what seems to me, like a cash cow attempt to milk the might and magic license from your friends at Ubi-soft.

If the late game is terrible, then I will add to the review, if it is good, I will also add to the review later.  Till then, I will, sort of recommend this game to folks.  Just watch my vids and see if you like what you get.

reviewText: Great game if you enjoy the appeal of Ye Olde' dungeon RPGs from the windows 95 era. All the fun without the hassle of floppy disks and mapping everything with a notepad and pencil. The story is great but you really have to pay attention as it can get quite confusing because there is so much to take in. Plays great and looks great, the sounds can get a bit trying at times especially the character emotes. Fairly challenging and can take quite a bit of strategy or if necessary grinding out a few levels. All in all I found it very enjoyable, but I'm a huge fan of this style of game, to the point where I still play Lands of Lore and other such titles on a DOS emulator. For me or other dungeon RPG fans I'd give it an 9/10, for the average player (especially one new to this genre) 7/10

reviewText:
Surprise, surprise, a new Might & Magic in 2014. And it's turn based. And has grid based movement. And is in first person. I had to do a double take, too, after that announcement. Although we had some Japanese games carry on the torch of such RPGs (Etrian Odyssey, Wizardry: Labyrinth of Lost Souls etc.) in recent years, they were fairly combat focused and simple.

This here is the real deal. It has (light) puzzles, lore in the form of books, an expansive overworld and multiple cities with shops, NPCs and quests. Character generation and development has a lot of options and you have to make hard choices because there are a lot more skills to develop than there are skill points.

The game has two difficulty modes and I played on the easier setting. I think I made the right choice as I felt the challenge was always so that I had to pay attention to enemy weaknesses and positioning but was never totally outmatched besides a few badly balanced battles. Oftentimes, in these new old school" games
date: you have to go straight to a higher difficulty to get a decent challenge but this just felt right. The game loves to ambush your party from all sides with no escape possible so I think this could get frustrating in a higher difficulty quickly.\n\nThe main satisfaction in these kind of games comes from getting loot
hoursPlayed: developing your characters and exploring new areas. I think the game absolutely delivers in these aspects
voteText: I almost never was bored in my 40 hours which it took me to beat the game with most sidequests done.\n\nThe graphics are nice and adequate for the budget they probably had but the performance could be better. Loading times are fairly long
helpfulPercent: too
votesHelpful: for 2013 mid-range game computer hardware with an SSD.\n\nI would welcome a Might & Magic XI after this successful revival of an old franchise."

reviewText: A relaxing and enjoyable game.  Similar in gameplay to some of the previous Might and Magic games as well as Legend of Grimrock.  Unlike Grimrock, you may be locked to a grid, but it isn't a click-fest.  Character skills are are turn-based, and it allows more of a relaxed progression on the game.  I have a toddler and a five year old, and I appreciate a game that doesn't punish me for having to split my attention.\n\nThe challenge level is good.  Some fights are easy while others are epic slug-fests you feel like you have to pull out all the stops to complete.  If you like turn-based games and/or RPGs, this one is worth a go.

reviewText: Terrific return to the series past, this installment is a return to form for this series after the disappointing M&M 9. Not quite up to the (rose tinted) M&M 6, this release is more in the vein of M&M 3 or 4; the old school charm is a welcome change of pace from “modern” RPG’s, and a reminder of how solid these games used to be. The only thing that could use further tweaking is the difficulty… Adventurer mode is too easy, while Warrior mode can be too unforgiving, especially in the early game. My advice is to play on Warrior mode, but read a class guide beforehand, as it is too easy to create a party and build that can’t progress in Act 2.\n\nLegacy is a bit rough around the edges, but if you are a fan of Might & Magic, or RPG’s in general, this one is well worth your time!

reviewText:
A couple of things to remind you how M&M works.
#1 Everyone in your party MUST have ranged AND melee weapons. Unlike other RPG's where you usually have only one or the other. It took me a bit to remember that this was the way M&M worked and you will fail if you don't have both.
#2 I was really frustrated with the controls, then I remembered that Q and E turn you around. You can change what buttons do that as well if you want something else.
If you do these two things and if you liked M&M before you will love this game.

reviewText: The mixed reviews put me off this game for a long while, but I finally picked it up and was pleasantly suprised. I'm a die-hard fan of Might and Magic VI, which I've gone back and played several times over the years. This installment lacks the scope of VI, but captures the spirit of it.\n\nPlanning and developing your party is the main highlight, despite a few minor issues with how skills are distributed across classes. Although there are party combinations that are clearly better" if you are optimizing
date: there are lots of possibilities that are doable and fun
recommended: even by just using different skill distributions amongst the same classes.\n\nYou have to accept that you can't get everything you want on every character or every party
hoursPlayed: since there is an effective limit on the experience you can gain in the game. This can be frustrating
voteText: but forces you build more intelligently and make sacrifices to get the skills you want. The game itself is somewhat linear and lacking in the open-world feel of other Might and Magic games. The story isn't very deep or compelling

with good replayability. Certainly better than the average review indicates. Now I'm primed to go back and play VI again.

reviewText:
Old school dungeon crawler. Turn based combat. Good for a relaxing game of nostaligic party based monster bashing, leveling, and loot collecting if you are into that kind of thing. I finally made it to act 2 on my 7th try playing hardcore mode (meaning I start over on a total party kill.).

It is a difficult, unforgiving game (at least on warrior mode). It won't hold your hand or give you quest arrows to follow. That is a quite refreshing change, having to explore and find things rather than mindlessly being spoon fed content.

After investing several hours, I began to realize that this game is VERY hard to beat, especially if you like to play hardcore mode, and blind without knowledge of the game. It's not possible to retreat unless you use a very specific obscure party build. So to play this hardcore you almost need to be spoiled in advance. So for the record I still think it's a great game, but it can't scratch that Dead is Dead game itch without some serious tweaking for me.

reviewText: The game has performance issues, especially around the 680gtx cards. Only uses the first card, and will pretty much peg it most of the game (bug). But the game is fun, and captures the original feel of might and magic 3-5.  The game is pretty well balances, difficult but most party combinations have a way to beat it. The Falchon and the Unicorn is very difficult, I got through the jail to the palace courtyard. after 100+ attempts I finally modded my archemage (which was healer/area dps) ac by 25, and vitality by 20 through gear  modifications. I also increased my warmongers ac by 25. This kept my whole party from being one hit and allowed my only healer to resurrect. I still had quite a challenge to get to the end, but at least it wasnt impossible. I am sure there are party and gear combinations that make it beatable but when you face 20+ enemies all capable of one shot kills (with several that can 1 shot party kill), with facing 6 at a time, it is very little odds that you will get lucky enough to survive. The one time I did, I had to reload because I couldn't resurrect my party.  If you mod start small, even 10% might be enough to make the difference.  I recommend it, its a fun old school rpg, but only if you like extreme challenges tackle falchon and the unicorn (or opt for some mods) don't mod before the dlc, it will ruin your whole experience the main game is well balanced.

reviewText: After putting 80+ hours into this game with two ongoing playthroughs I definitely recommend Might and Magic X: Legacy.  At first I was slow to succumb to its charms.  I felt the controls and immersion were a little clumsy, the voices and sound effects cheesy at best, and the visuals less than stellar.  When I got to the heart of the game, however, all of those things faded to the background and I found a lot to enjoy in the party building, monster smashing, and exploration.  I encourage newcomers to begin with an open mind and to be prepared to invest some solid time with a trial party to get acquainted with the mechanics and to learn what works well and what doesn't. Then once you have a vision and some goals it makes the challenges in front of you - and your progress - much more rewarding and motivating.\n\nI'm enjoying mysecond playthrough even more, this time using my knowledge of trainer and gear availability, what works best in combat and what doesn't, and an understanding of the pacing of the game to make a challenging party that beats the odds.  What's more, the game is deliberately set up to prevent you from trying all of the skills and classes in one go.  At first this frustrated me; now I appreciate the built-in replay.  A tip on that note: Don't try to do it all, do just a few things really well, and then try a different mix in another playthrough.

reviewText:
Might & Magic X - Legacy is a game that has problems. Especially for fans of the series it will be big irritating shock to suddenly find this game to have tile-based movements, which at least in my opinion limits the world, that is open to one, massively. (This world feels a lot smaller than the ones we had in the last games!) Now again this is at first terribly annoying, but as the time goes on, one eventually starts to live over that movement system. However the part about going on can become a bit problematic.
Even now, after the game has left Steam Early Access, it's still terribly unbalanced to play and it definitely isn't unusual to experience multiple crashes. And apperantly that isn't something that's dependent on having a high-end PC or not, since it might play just fine on my old laptop for several hours and on my Tower-PC it crashes every 15 minutes or vise versa. To counter that I've made it a habit of mine to quick-save almost every 10 steps and after every fight.

The fact that they included several (actually many) references to the previous Heroes games (which is logical since they're in the storyline of the series the most recent ones) is nice untill you start to get to the point where you're starting to realize that they just took most of the units from those Heroes games, kept their animation cycles, scaled and brushed them up a bit and then plastered them everywhere...

The story itself is fairly nicely written, eventhough I can see some minor mistakes or nonsense here and there. Again all in all the story that's being told is failry enjoyable. And since that's in fact the only thing that I've been interested in, in almost all the games of the series so far, I'll still recommend it, despite all the flaws I mentioned beforehand.

reviewText:
Highly recommended!  Fans of old-school first person RPGs really shouldn't miss out on this gem.  It's very true to the feel of Might and Magic 3, 4, and 5 (some of the most fun RPGs ever!).  It's really obvious that a lot of passion went into it, thanks Limbic!  Thanks too to Ubisoft for being a AAA publisher that is actually taking a chance of a retro-indie game!

Oh, and a quick note for anybody who is having the issues with blurry, really low-res textures: make sure you go to the MAIN MENU and change the textures to a higher quality, there is a small bug right now where changing some of the settings from the in-game menu doesn't work.

Happy adventuring everybody!

reviewText:
Cons
Horribly long load times, easily 15-30 seconds for an area.  There are cases where if you want to run back to town, you will need to run through 4+ areas.  With movement and load times this can take easily five minutes.  Too make it even more annoying the loading of an area STOPS if the screen loses focus, so no alt-tabbing during a load time.
This is simply too immersion breaking.   There is a good chance you will hit a point where you have to run back to town realize this could easily involve five minutes to get there and then ANOTHER five minutes to get back.  If you’re the type of person who will drop this game and forget it with the above scenario don’t buy it.


Pros
Probably the best combat system for a turn based RPG I’ve seen in a long time.
Melee for example you have the three styles, duel-wield, shield and two-hander each one has situations where one is better.  A monster has the ability vindictive, for every miss on him he gets one more hit, which might damages your whole party.  Duel wielding dagger wielders with 4 attacks might get you killed if they miss too often one round, while a two handers one swing mass damage won’t cause a wipe.   Conversely a monster might be able to block the first swing against him 75% of the time, making the duel wielder at worst lose one attack and the two-hander do none.
The spells are just as varied and important as well with their effects frequently being more important than their damage.   Pushing a monster square away, putting a monster to sleep, reducing the number of attacks a monster gets, buffing the party, removing block attempts or armour from monsters, AoE spells, and many more effects.
Although some fights do break down into a simple damage race, knowing what type of melee and spell to use and the correct order actually matters in this game.

reviewText: I think this game is worth playing.  It's very refreshing to play a challenging rpg and something  different from the current crop of modern action rpgs.  I first I was a little put off with the way the skill system worked, and it took me a few to get used to grid movement and the battles were tough.  Then I got engaged.  Instead of just brute forcing my way (which didnt work) I started to think a little more tactically, and began planning my battles, what spells I would use, how I would skill up and basically just think ahead. This game is about resource management, managing your mana, managing your potions and managing your gold as drops aren't as abundant as they are in other games.   So I started off thinking the game was ok, to, wow this is fantastic. And all it took was adjusting my mindset. My only gripes are that I wish there was a way to tactically withdraw from fights instead of being locked in, and I would have enjoyed a few monster respawns (once you clear an area it stays clear) so I could farm a little more xp and pad my cash balance and items a little more. I'm not overly fond of having to have uplay as well but it is not very intrusive. There could be a little more explanation of various game aspects as well, but overall I am very happy with this purchase.

reviewText:
This classic type RPG can be described like revive of the 90's Western RPG based on turn system.

There are many positive clues to prove this game is fine.

If I say one of them, I strongly want to focus to say the play of this game pull the player up.



The duty to meet the ending when u play RPG is you must develop ur character.

So, the player have to do many things like hunting, farming and seeking until they get enough level and items to go front.

I am sure the most important point which RPG player abandon or keep playing is this time.




But the Might & Magic X - Legacy has quitly defended itself from the problems.

Might & Magic X - Legacy is based for old-type RPG but it also show u fine quility of adventure.

The game show the route which player have to follow but the player do not need to do it first.

You can find many interesting secrets, items, and bonuses that's used for ur journey before u are on the board of the main quest.

What I need to say is this charm is quite variety and fun. and the reward of ur action is clear, fair, and very helpful.

Of course, still there are several flaw to disturb player like bugs, transporting system, and puzzles.

But, the experiences of all of them is unique and u can feel fresh in everytime that u travel new map and dungeons.

reviewText: Wow, what a game.  Haven't seen an old school RPG like this in years, and they really hit the nail on the head.  Game uses a first person grid based system similar to Legend Of Grimrock, but it is much more complex.  You choose a party of 4 adventurers, and are free to mix and match as you please.  The leveling system is well thought out and there is definitely lots of room for strategy in skill choice and combat mechanics.  Game appears to be quite long, and the difficulty on Warrior" mode is quite challenging.  If you are a fan of classic RPG's

recommended: but once you are in game you will forget all about it."

reviewText:
One of the best reiterations of an old series into a new game, using turn based old RPG tactics.  This has been one of the most fun and challenging RPGs I've played of late in regards to gameplay and high fantasy themed environments, monsters, and NPCs.

What this game lacks:  Story.  It's not that great compared to some RPGs like The Witcher series.  It's a basic plot line like other old school RPGs, but the gameplay highly makes up for that.

Minor issues:  Some graphical screen stuttering when moving around some areas, but not a big deal.

reviewText: After putting 80+ hours into this game with two ongoing playthroughs I definitely recommend Might and Magic X: Legacy.  At first I was slow to succumb to its charms.  I felt the controls and immersion were a little clumsy, the voices and sound effects cheesy at best, and the visuals less than stellar.  When I got to the heart of the game, however, all of those things faded to the background and I found a lot to enjoy in the party building, monster smashing, and exploration.  I encourage newcomers to begin with an open mind and to be prepared to invest some solid time with a trial party to get acquainted with the mechanics and to learn what works well and what doesn't. Then once you have a vision and some goals it makes the challenges in front of you - and your progress - much more rewarding and motivating.\n\nI'm enjoying mysecond playthrough even more, this time using my knowledge of trainer and gear availability, what works best in combat and what doesn't, and an understanding of the pacing of the game to make a challenging party that beats the odds.  What's more, the game is deliberately set up to prevent you from trying all of the skills and classes in one go.  At first this frustrated me; now I appreciate the built-in replay.  A tip on that note: Don't try to do it all, do just a few things really well, and then try a different mix in another playthrough.

reviewText: The game has performance issues, especially around the 680gtx cards. Only uses the first card, and will pretty much peg it most of the game (bug). But the game is fun, and captures the original feel of might and magic 3-5.  The game is pretty well balances, difficult but most party combinations have a way to beat it. The Falchon and the Unicorn is very difficult, I got through the jail to the palace courtyard. after 100+ attempts I finally modded my archemage (which was healer/area dps) ac by 25, and vitality by 20 through gear  modifications. I also increased my warmongers ac by 25. This kept my whole party from being one hit and allowed my only healer to resurrect. I still had quite a challenge to get to the end, but at least it wasnt impossible. I am sure there are party and gear combinations that make it beatable but when you face 20+ enemies all capable of one shot kills (with several that can 1 shot party kill), with facing 6 at a time, it is very little odds that you will get lucky enough to survive. The one time I did, I had to reload because I couldn't resurrect my party.  If you mod start small, even 10% might be enough to make the difference.  I recommend it, its a fun old school rpg, but only if you like extreme challenges tackle falchon and the unicorn (or opt for some mods) don't mod before the dlc, it will ruin your whole experience the main game is well balanced.

reviewText:
I will never understand why this game has so many negative reviews.

Does this game require Uplay to boot up in the background?  Yes.

Does it interfere with gameplay or is it clunky?  No, at least not for me.  It boots in the background and sits there quietly.

Does this game play like most other of the newer Might and Magic games?  No, from what I've read.

However, this game, specifically this game is the game I have been looking for, for YEARS.  This game plays like Grimrock 1/2, if you've ever played those.  It's a 100% turn-based, dungeon-crawling RPG, and I think it's brilliant.  It has an open world, tons of loot and quests to do, and pretty decent graphics (I have them maxed with a gtx 760 2GB DDR5 RAM, and then 8 GB normal RAM.

I love this game a lot.  I've already put 10ish hours into it, and I feel like there's a lot more coming, and I've only finished the first Act of the game.

I got this on sale with the DLC for $7.50, I would have easily paid $20+ if I'd known I was going to enjoy it this much.  If you've never played a game like this, and you have the money, it doesn't hurt to give it a shot.

If you like turn-based party RPGs, this is your gig man, get in here and have some fun.  8/10

Missions are really nice, the only one  i wasn't enjoyed was the Grand Master Arcane Discipline and waiting 1 month, graphics for me wasn't bad but could be better in some places, still one of my favourite RPGs i played. I recommend this game for every player who liked older Might and Magic's!

reviewText:
This game is old school.  Grid based movement; turn based combat; we go/you go combat mechanics and other classic game systems like from M&M 1-5.  If your looking for top notch graphics,  a free move mode like in Skyrim, twitch based fights, and hand holding quests/fights,  you'll be sorely disapointed.

But if your looking for a modernish remake of an old classic CRPG, that brings back so many memories of classic M&M/Xeen games of the past, this game will certainly give you plenty of enjoyment.

But, it also has horrible, terrible optimization problems, with lag and low FPS even on the best systems, and lock-ups on 32bit systems are being reported.  So sad they released such a classic remake in such terrible shape.

reviewText:
Do not buy.

Once your enganged in melee you can not move until you get yourself out, usally by pushing the mob back with something like gust of wind. That moves them back one square. Oh wait you already cast so you cant move until the next round. Now the mob moves back in range. So you need 2 casters to disengage if possible. But the first 3 bosses are immune to knock back and deal increased damage if you block or dodge their attacks.Celestial armor abosrbs X amount of physical damage. It does not stop you from getting poisoned or taking poison damage. Theres several spots where you have to fight multiple ranged opponents at once and they get the drop on you.

Did I mention I was playing this on adventurer and Ive beaten wizardry 8?

reviewText:
Why I don't recommend it...

Purchased this yesterday, full version.

Complete act 1...

Wander around like a chicken with my head chopped off, revisiting all the NPC's re-checking all the areas.

Can't enter act 2... After a couple hours of blinding fumbling in the dark, I go look on the forums.  Oh looksee the game has a bug that affects pretty much everyone preventing you from getting into act 2.

And why might you ask is a bug enough of a reason to rate a game 1/10?

Well its simple...  THEY PROGRAMMED THE BUG INTO THE GAME.  It was an intentionally put in block during the beta stage of the game, they did this intentionally and failed to remove the block for the full version...

Just pathetic... utterly pathetic.

reviewText:
So many things about Might and Magic – Legacy are just needlessly stupid. If you get poisoned  then there seems to be only two things that will cure it, the antidote potion or death. And guess what? The first portion of the game is filled with spiders that poison you repeatedly in every single fight. So, a level one spider, can poison you and do what is effectively an endless amount of damage. You can use every single health potion that you have and the poison effect never wears off. If you run out of antidote potions in the first mission then you are are just screwed as far as I can tell.

Do you want to make a unique character? How about a tough spear wielding druid? Well, if there is no spear in the shop then you  can't attack. You can cast your one staring spell two or three times and then your mana has run out and you stand there.

Mechanics are completely unexplained, as is leveling so are basic explanations of pretty much everything. This should be a great game that is completely ruined through sheer boneheaded decisions.

reviewText: Having participated in the early-access program and completing the early stages of the game several times, and helping the developers out as they progress through the game's developerment, I can say I am so far pleased with the final product. While the game is completly tile based, it does make you think about every step you end up taking, as it uses a turn. If you have a buff, do you want to move this direction or this direction, either way it uses up a point in the spell's duration. The graphics are pretty, although it can be a little laggy even on high end machines it isn't anything to start ranting about. If you are a fan of the older type of RPG's like this, you can even set the game to retro mode" in the options and force the older feel pixels for the game. The game is filled with all sorts of journals giving insight to the world the game is set in. I personally sat down (breaks included of going to make a sandwich or something else more important at the moment) for a little over 3 hours to find the perfect type of class combination I wanted for my party. It is very important that you choose wisely. The game encourages you to explore the areas you are in and do not strictly require you to go from point A to point B. The way I see it is
date: take a shot at getting it. If you get the amout of hours in gameplay that you paid for it
recommended: then its worth the purchase. Try to avoid the ones that pick at the minor flaws and give it a bad rating."

reviewText:
For anyone who thought that MM6 and MM7 were the best games in the series, this game is a huge let down. The developers took the best part of the game series, the sandbox element, and replaced it with a linear piece of junk.

There were three aspects of the game that I enjoyed, the riddles and/or puzzles, being able to gather most quest objects without having the quest active yet (it saved me a lot of running around and back-tracking), and the fallout-style epilogue for some of the completed quests, that I got after beating the game. It could have given me a little extra time to read them, but whatever.

That said, those are the only three elements of the game that I enjoyed and if I had to rate the game on a scale of one to ten, I'd say it'd rate a three with their inclusion.

The rest is just full of dross, I beat the game and started today on the Falcon and the Unicorn DLC. Got fed up when it just transported me to the dungeon and dumped all the stuff I had. Even if I would have gotten my things back by getting to the second level of said dungeon, the approach and how it handled the interaction does not make sense to me.

Having said all of this, I can forgive a lot if there is a good story included in a game.

The story given is a piece of crap. The more I think about diffent elements in it, the less it makes sense to me.

It is presented in such a way as to celebrate how humans can do anything, while slandering the names of two real-life angels according to the bible, and presenting the policy of the separation of church and state as something that is needed because the angels are the corrupt element in the government. This just doesn't make sense to me in a fictional world, where as far as I know every other supernatural being is given a made up name. Why go to the trouble of offending people who believe the two named angels are real beings in the real world, and one of which is described in the book of Daniel as the Great Prince who protects the Jews? The writer could have just as easily made up another name for these mortal non-angels as they are presented in the world.

There are other issues I have with the game, lots of them, but you don't need to hear general griping from me. Just suffice to say that my personal tastes find this game to be extremely lacking on several levels, despite looking forward to playing it since I heard that it was being made.

Some may claim that I'm setting the bar too high, but I think it's high enough for an expectation of what to expect from a game calling itself 'Might+Magic x:Legacy' when the Wizardry series ended on an awesome note with Wizardry 8. I can play Wizardry 8 to this day and have an awesome time, but I can tell you all that I'm never touching this piece of crap again. Later! Time to play Wizardry 7, I want to see what I can do with a party starting W8 as allies of the other races...

reviewText:
If you play this, for the love of ♥♥♥♥ please design your own party.

I knew the default group would suck plentiful rods, so I played it (on Hard) to handicap myself, and holy hell did I overestimate them. They are the most incompetent buffoons I've ever been dealt. Its a good game though, if you like this genre. I haven't beaten it yet, but if I ever manage to drag these hopeless clowns through Hard mode, I'll probably just retire from gaming, as nothing could top that feat.

reviewText: When this game was first released, turned out that Uplay gave Steam Standard keys instead of Deluxe keys.  Steam is making an effort to fix the screw-up that Uplay caused; Might & Magic VI has already been made available for download as a separate download & the soundtrack became availabe for download after I got a response to my support ticket.  The DLC included in the package are still up in the air due to the fact that Uplay currently has Standard keys applied to our Uplay accounts, so the only way this is going to be resolved is if Steam gives us DLC keys for those when they are released so that we can apply them to our Uplay accounts.  Receiving a key for THE FALCON AND THE UNICORN should be easy enough, but THE DREAM SHARD DUNGEON doesn't actually state that it's DLC, so I somehow don't expect that we're going to be able to get this unless Uplay makes a special exception & provides Steam with keys for it considering they screwed us Steam customers over.  Considering Uplay's disgusting behavior to this whole situation since the beginning, I have to expect that this won't be happening.  If we're lucky, it will be released as DLC regardless since I don't see any other way we're going to get that content if not.\n\nUPDATE: Seems Ubi is playing the blame game in this matter. Anybody going to Ubisoft to get the status on their Uplay account corrected is getting turned away & told to go back to where they purchased it from. This only shows that Ubisoft is not willing to work with 3rd-party distributors & only gives me the impression that this may have been done on purpose. Worst part is I now have a Standard version of the key stuck on my Uplay account that Ubisoft won't even hear from users that didn't purchase the game directly from their store. I think I'm probably done with purchasing from Ubisoft at this point.  I was doing the same with Steam until I realized they are definitely making an effort to rectify this issue, so I ended that & will continue to purchase from Steam so long as games are not by other companies on my boycott list (EA, Blizzard & now Ubisoft if they keep playing this game).

reviewText: Being an old school Might and Magic fan, I didn't know what to expect out of this game. I played through and got to the end but it took a while. Save and save often. Your party make-up in the beginning makes a BIG difference in your survivability rate. Don't make any archers, bring someone that can take a lot of dmg, bring someone that can deal lots of dmg, make sure you have a good healer and have someone that can cast pretty much all the spells. You might have to try out a few combinations before you figure out what's best. If you like the Might and Magic series, you will dig this game. The only gripe is the class customization. I was hoping for a bit more than what was offered. Pretty much have to take it or leave it kinda classes. Make a good combination of classes and you can't go wrong. This game kinda reminds me of playing the older ones with the turn-based movement. The game looks great, but be prepared for a bit of a challenge until you get some levels.

reviewText:
IT'S MIGHT AND MAGIC ♥♥♥♥♥EEEEESS!

Post-completion review:

Ok so, I've been playing Might and Magic games since 1997 and finished every campaign for any and all games with M&M title that came out since then. I've completed M&M6 about 10 times and rest of the games in the series at least 3 times each.

Keeping that in mind, I didn't hesitate to buy a game from the franchise, which was though to be dead, and frankly is not appealing to the younger generation of players. It is a great gamble to publish a game like this and I thank Limbic and Ubisoft (which I actually don't like very much).

However, accepting the reality of this game's probability of success for modern player base and the monetary resources devoted to the game are no doubt limited, the game feels very incomplete" in every way.

As much as i can see on the internet
date: people ♥♥♥♥♥ about the grid based/turn based mechanics of the game. My personal problem however is not about it's mechanics but about it's setup. Game is considerably short (finished in 45 hours or so. In M&M 6 you can't even clear 3 cities and related regions/quests in that time) and game world is extremely small. Entirety of M&M X sums up to 2-3 regions in M&M 6
recommended: 7 or 8. Considering that M&M 6 had 12 regions and MASSIVE dungeons
hoursPlayed:
M&M X is a huge disappointment in that regard.

My second problem with the game is the linearity story. M&M games always had that freedom feeling (not like the sandbox games like TES series of course) which allowed the player to go to Dragonsand at level 1 and instantly ♥♥♥♥♥ by 200 dragons in range.

The story itself in previous games also had a classic purpose of gathering up different factions against a common enemy
voteText: then going in solo to crash it. M&M X lacks this quest line too
helpfulPercent: as we are getting railroaded into a single minded purpose. In M&M 7 the light vs dark choice had a game changing effect
votesHelpful: and less so in 8. M&M X doesn't have this story feature as it lacks any type of choice over the story.\n\nThere are also issues with the game mechanics themselves. The class promotions are almost useless to get (which were CRITICAL to have in previous games)
votesTotal: and the lack of honorary promotion quests breaks some of the dungeons (like if you don't have a paladin in your party
votesFunny: you can't complete the quest about shantiri disc). Skills are restructured and the removal of most miscelenaous skills (like lockpick
commentsCount: merchant
column16: armsmaster
column17: disarm
column18: repair
column19: identify item
column20: etc.) makes the game more combat oriented than before.\n\nOn the positive side of things
column21: the setting of the game was done quite well with the "new" world of Ashan. After the failure of M&M 9 and it's poorly thought setting
column22:
M&M X used the story began with Heroes 6 quite well. Race specific classes were also a great idea and made the game replayable (for me at least)

My evaluation of the game in general comes down to these:
- Very short story
- VERY small game world
- Too linear storyline and the lack of choice
- Bugs (less than I expected actually)
- Poor game engine performance
+ Franchise connected backstory
+ Large number of classes for replayability
+ 4 player party system and turn based combat
+ BEING A MIGHT AND MAGIC GAME

7/10



PS: If the game gets a few DLCs to make it longer (like twice longer or something) and add regions like a city from Irollan

reviewText: If you played and enjoyed the old Might and Magic games this is a great piece of nostalgia-ware with better graphics and an updated interface. I also enjoyed the expanded class and skill system. If you explore all the content it will consume many hours of your time - you definitely get your money's worth. I restarted the early part of the game a few times to change parties, but once I found a group I liked, I played it all the way through and really enjoyed it. Recommended for old school CRPG gamers who like turn-based combat like I do or who liked the original Might and Magic games like I did.

reviewText:
Might and Magic 6 and 7 were some of my favorite games when they came out. The combination of an intricate skill system and open world gameplay was addictive as hell. Fortunately this new installment in the series captures the same feeling that made those games great. In fact it even improves on many aspects. The first major difference is combat. Instead of being realtime/pausable, the combat is completely turn based. This makes battles much more about tactics then the previous might and magics. The skill system with masters and grandmasters makes a return along with class promotion quests. In fact, this game retains a lot of might and magic staples. Yes there is obelisks. Yes there are relics.

Dungeons are very well done. There are secrets and hidden passages that you must find. You cant just kill all the enemies to finish the dungeons/quests. Dungeons are large and there is even one that has multiple entries and exits that span a large part of the game world. You will find yourself returning to the different dungeons just to see if you missed anything. You will solve puzzles, find clues, and even discover elemental shards. There are about 7 shards in total and each time you find one, you embark on a quest and gain a new blessing. The blessing's allow you to cross water or cut through a forest or take portals.

Might and Magic X can be difficult and even frustrating at times. The magic system is such that you gain new spells when you become an expert, master, or grandmaster. You will find yourself to weak to fight certain creatures until you get these new spells. Speaking of the spell system, there are 12 different classes spanning 4 different races. Each class has its own flavor and can specialize in certain skills. Once your class gets promoted, they even get special abilities. This was a great addition to the traditional Might and Magic class system.

The one downside to this game is that its not quite big enough. You can tell the developers didnt have the time or budget they needed to truly make an epic game. I believe this release was a sort of test to see how well itd do and if it does well, we can look foward to a epic Might and Magic XI. Although the game world is small, its still a fantastic game.

reviewText: I am big fun of Might and Magic series, but fatal bugs make this game unplayable.
voteText: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Might and Magic. Right. Not to be confused with the Heroes of Might and Magic series, which, went down the minute UbiSoft got the IP.

This game has it flaws, actually many flaws. I'll note some cons of the game;

- No front and rear positions- Your heroes are all in the front rank, and can be targeted by the enemies, so you cannot defend your magic users. There are a few spells which take some of the damage, but not having front and rear ranks is a bit of a oversight.
- No means of retreating- Sometimes you make a mistake and aggro the wrong enemies, once you are locked into combat you cannot move away. So if you bite off more than you can chew; just load a previous save and save you the trouble of fighting a lost battle.
- The graphics are really below par. Ofcourse graphics are not the most important things in these sort of games, but 2014 would mean at least some more eye-candy would be welcome. The graphics are bland, doors and NPCs made as if they are from the nineties. The day and night cycle is good though, but overall the graphics are not 2014 like,
- The levelling up is way too much fuss. You'd think when you level up you can select abilities and skills on one screen. Not in this game; Here you need to edit your stats in the inventory screen, close it, open the spellbook and select more skill points for weapon/spells/etc. skills. Very annoying.
- The customisation options- Really, 4 races with only 2 head options for females and males? Three classes per race is way too few. Customisation is very, very disappointing.
- The Dialogues- Dialogues are very boring; If you expect anything like Mass Effect think again. Not much options to answer, usually only 2 and the dialogues really don't draw you into the story.
- The graphics sometimes don't render and there are slow-downs at certain parts. Bad graphical optimisation.

I can go on, but I think you get a general idea. Does this game have no plusses? Sure, but the cons really have the upper hand. Wait for a few more patches which hopefully will change a lot while the game feels very rushed.

I think hardcore fans of the Might and Magic series could get some fun out of this game, but people like me, who like the Eye of the Beholder series and Wizardry 8, really don't need to buy this. It is overpriced and under-par. It tries to mimick the RPGs of old and fails.

Shame really while it had potential to become a great game.

reviewText: Might & Magic X combines old-school sensibilities with a modern UI and a deep world of monsters just waiting to destroy your carefully built party. There is no tutorial, there are no quest markers and the game over screen is Death laughing at your failure. If you hold classic Might and Magic dear to your heart, this is a no brainer: Might & Magic X is a worthy offering to the throne of Jon Van Caneghem. If you've never played the series, it's a great example of what classic RPG's were all about.\n\nGrab a drink, shut the blinds and say goodbye to your life...one tile at a time.

reviewText:
Might and Magic 6 and 7 were some of my favorite games when they came out. The combination of an intricate skill system and open world gameplay was addictive as hell. Fortunately this new installment in the series captures the same feeling that made those games great. In fact it even improves on many aspects. The first major difference is combat. Instead of being realtime/pausable, the combat is completely turn based. This makes battles much more about tactics then the previous might and magics. The skill system with masters and grandmasters makes a return along with class promotion quests. In fact, this game retains a lot of might and magic staples. Yes there is obelisks. Yes there are relics.

Dungeons are very well done. There are secrets and hidden passages that you must find. You cant just kill all the enemies to finish the dungeons/quests. Dungeons are large and there is even one that has multiple entries and exits that span a large part of the game world. You will find yourself returning to the different dungeons just to see if you missed anything. You will solve puzzles, find clues, and even discover elemental shards. There are about 7 shards in total and each time you find one, you embark on a quest and gain a new blessing. The blessing's allow you to cross water or cut through a forest or take portals.

Might and Magic X can be difficult and even frustrating at times. The magic system is such that you gain new spells when you become an expert, master, or grandmaster. You will find yourself to weak to fight certain creatures until you get these new spells. Speaking of the spell system, there are 12 different classes spanning 4 different races. Each class has its own flavor and can specialize in certain skills. Once your class gets promoted, they even get special abilities. This was a great addition to the traditional Might and Magic class system.

The one downside to this game is that its not quite big enough. You can tell the developers didnt have the time or budget they needed to truly make an epic game. I believe this release was a sort of test to see how well itd do and if it does well, we can look foward to a epic Might and Magic XI. Although the game world is small, its still a fantastic game.

New revised opinion.

Once Uplay managed to sort out the mess with the CD key and access to their servers, I managed to put some time into the game.  Overall, I'm enjoying the experience, it's a fun game and anyone who enjoys turn based RPGs will love it.  There are some really great encounters to be had, I really enjoyed the boss fights - seemingly impossible encounters become doable once you put some thought into how you will approach the fight - I like that in a game. I really hope they will release more content as this game has a lot of promise.  It needs polishing - some of the quests don't quite work in their timing, because of the way many areas are locked out until you reach certain goals you receive some quests that can't be resolved until much later in the game and annoyingly you also solve some quests earlier than you receive them (so you end up getting the quest and completing the quest in at the same time) - minor points reallyu, but I hope the devs look into it to create a more polished overall game.

reviewText:
After some installing issues and finishing the game, I can give a proper review.

Initially I had problems running the game after install; which I fixed by forcing Administrator Rights in Windows.  Before this, the game would crash with an error report every single time.  This took several hours of trial-and-error, during which I was not very happy.

Having not played any of the other series before this one, I can say that the combat style is turned based, similar to say... Final Fantasy 7 turned-based.  Navigation through the world is tile-based, which I didn't like or dislike; since the graphic scenery was consistently believable enough.  There are some load time issues while traversing the world and I was getting bad frame rates in some areas.  The graphics are mostly above-average but occasionally there are some very poorly textured objects.
I did not find any game-ending bugs but there were some plot-line bugs and companion NPC's  working incorrectly like the Negotiator NPC not giving the proper discount for goods.

Plot-wise & quest-wise, the game held my attention enough for me to complete it from start to end.  I took my time finishing the game and even restarted several times to test out new class combinations.  It honestly took me about a week to finish but- as I said- I was learning the game and restarting several times.  There is a hard starting condition where your party has practically nothing and needs everything to survive- new equipment, new spells, new general knowledge to learn about the surrounding area, and a tide of quests to complete.  This is the funnest part of the game for me, due to the difficulty.  About mid-game it becomes apparent that your characters have every inventory slot filled (some with uber-powerful relics), necessary spells purchased & learned, with skill trees grand-mastered--- and while I would have liked the enemies, especially the bosses, to scale they did not.  A lot of the boss fights towards end game were simply the same exact spell casting order that I used to kill the lesser enemies on the plains.  This is when the difficulty practically tapers off.  Towards the end-game I distinctly remember several boss battles where I stayed at range and casted the same 2 ranged spells by my mages; meanwhile the boss couldn't even out-damage the base-line regen spell cast at the start of battle.  The boss inevitably dies to simple attrition and I get an uber relic.  Battles like this are stress-free and the most relaxing battles ever fought, but the fun-factor suffers greatly.

After finishing the game I think the final score lies somewhere between around 80/100.  Due to bugs I might drop that score down a bit since there are a lot of bugs that need to be addressed.  Then again, the asking price is what makes the game worthwhile at a little over $20 so regardless a score of 80 feels justified.  It is a thumbs-up.
