reviewText:
I have always been a M&M loyal friend.  Even though I considered IX one of the worst of the main series, once I saw X:Legacy, I jumped on it like a kid on cake.  When I found out they went back to the original mechanics of grid-based movement, I was intrigued.  I grew up with I-V, and although I really enjoyed VI-VIII, there's something special about keeping true to the game that started it all.

Now that I've covered my background story, here's my main review points for X:Legacy.

First, it's raw... as in Early Access Beta  Test" raw.  I discovered early on that if a conversation with an NPC is a bit long in narration
date: it's cut off early.  I really wanted to hear more of what the Guard Captain of Sorpigal-by-the-Sea after his Quest was completed.\n\nSecond
recommended: when I toured the city and found the "Training Grounds"... I expected that to be the place I would level my characters.  This has been the case for 9 games
hoursPlayed: but when I found out I can level... for FREE... on the SPOT!  I was shocked...   I really don't know if that's a good or bad thing.\n\nThird

reviewText:
I just completed it and overall absolutely loved it. The old-fashioned controls work fine once you get used to them and add a bit of strategic gameplay that would otherwise be missing. It doesn't hold your hand so you'll probably restart a few times after messing up or because you want to try to optimize your party, but that was fine for me.

It can be frustrating at points and for a game that relies on a lot of quicksaves and loads - you will die a lot - loading was very slow.

A minor niggle: there's basically zero NPC AI or immersion. It almost impressively bad, e.g., when you solve the mystery in the first location for example the NPC texts involving the mystery don't change at all. Everyone has the same single line of text.

reviewText: If you played and enjoyed the old Might and Magic games this is a great piece of nostalgia-ware with better graphics and an updated interface. I also enjoyed the expanded class and skill system. If you explore all the content it will consume many hours of your time - you definitely get your money's worth. I restarted the early part of the game a few times to change parties, but once I found a group I liked, I played it all the way through and really enjoyed it. Recommended for old school CRPG gamers who like turn-based combat like I do or who liked the original Might and Magic games like I did.

reviewText: Over all, for the price and type of game, I'd recommend it. You just don't see a lot of games of this style being made anymore, so it's almost a matter of beggars can't be choosers
date:
unfortunately. That said, the game does come with a caveat emptor or two - when I played it, well after release and the first patch or two, I didn't really experience any huge problems. That said, some people do experience some game-breaking bugs, so your mileage may well vary!

Tha said, it's a spot-on solid homage to the older style of party-based first-person turn-based grid-based adventury games! There's secrets, spells, NPCs and quests, puzzles aplenty, riddles to answer, quests to do, etc. etc. At this point the game seems to be pretty playable and most bugs are work-aroundable at worst, though again it may just be that I got lucky, it's hard to say!

Each race has its own set of classes with their own unique promotion/promotion skill, skillsets, and so forth. The game starts out pretty smoothly and progresses nicely in terms of difficulty and character strength - I did feel my melee characters ended up a bit too strong by the end, but my magey fellow caught up right at the end-game, finally. It's really a pretty solid RPG of the style, and the only thing around since Grimrock (which isn't quite the same, anyways, though solid in its own right.)

reviewText:
While the concept is excellent, the implementation leaves a lot to be desired.

Main issue:
Buggy to the point of unplayable, REQUIRING hex-editing save games in order to progress due to bugs getting you stuck in combat with something that isn't there.

Extremely unintuitive on where to go, possible to win one fight, take three steps, and get 1 shot by something you have no business being near.

Unnecessarily long load times due to save game bloat, again needing a hex editor to fix

Supply limit can be extremely frustrating, gearing your characters can be extremely frustrating, walking all the way back to the very first town for training can be extremely frustrating, especially since every time you zone you get a 60 second load screen that may or may not result in your characters being stuck and unable to move when it finishes.  Can't simply reload the autosave, you'll still be stuck.  Must boot up the hex editor again.

After 6 or 7 times of this, I was done and regret spending the money until this is fixed.

reviewText:
Hello,

here is my review of Might & Magic X - Legacy:

first off there is no free modding kit like advertised in the shop. To use the mod kit you have to download UnityPro, after 30 days unityPro costs 1500$ once or 75$ per month to use. 32 bit users are getting screwed because they have no sound effects and are reduced to middle grafic settings. So false advertising at work in the shop.

It uses Ubisoft launcher as second layer of drm, isnt it fun? Problems with your internet connection? Bad luck you will not be able to play it.

The technical aspect of the game is horrible. On 32 bit system the game is incomplete, you get only middle textures, no party sounds, no monster sounds and other features are missing. The overall performance is bad. On 64 bit you get hight textures, animations and all but it does not look too good at all. That would be tolerable, roleplaying games are mostly about gameplay and not super grafic quality. But the performance is supbar compared to the grafic quality delivered. It runs really choppy and many systems. Even on the latest 780 gforce power rigs it does not run smooth so that is that. Performancewise it is a catastrophe.

Gameplay: 12 classes Defender, Bladedancer, Ranger, Mecenary , Freemage, Shaman, Druid, Runepriest, Barbarian, Scout, Crusader. Unfortunately ranged classes like the ranger and scout are useless farther into the game. You have very little opportunity to fight monsters at range, in melee they do next to no damage, because the main ranged stat perception does not improve the damageoutput of melee much.

The Ranger gets a point blank shot, this does not really help to improve his damage output. Magic classes are strong until the monsters get rediculous high resistance against their magic school. Most monster are resistent against a magic school or general resistent against all magic, so tough luck if your chosen magic school like fire or wind does nothing against that special pack of monsters or the boss. Magic user tend to burn your mana potion resources like mana addicts.

Defender, Bladedance and Crusader perform very good, the blade dancer with daggers buffed up by crusader spells is the best damage dealer in the game by a wide margin. He is so op that it brakes the whole class system. You will struggle without a bladedancer or barbarian as damage dealer in your party.

The whole class system is borked and unbalanced

The combat relies very much on luck and potion chucking, It does not feel very might and magic like in the later stages of the game. With a suboptimal(no bladedancer or two)  party you get one tough as nails fight after the other, in m&m series the game would throw many easy monsters at you to test your resource managementskills and use of aid spells, but not one hard battle after the other. The pacing is frustrating and not fun even on the easier adventurer mode. The encounterdesign is not good, it is one overly hard battle after the other, even for trash monsters. There is no respawn, the monster count is too low to succed by grinding. M&m x is the only rpg i know where i can't win through overleveling, so for me it is no rpg at all. Leveling your character through grinding, getting better equipment, farming gold, leveling skills is what makes a good rpg for me.

the skill system is more might and magic like. It is very rudimental and easy. You have 4 skillpoints per level to invest in your skills, after 7 15 20 skillpoints you can upgrade to a new skilltier, expert, master, grandmaster, you will get boni for each upgrade. Some skills are more powerfull then others. So magic skills get 5% 10% 15% spell penetration and more resistance against that magic school while the infamous dagger skill gets expert 1 extra attack and plus hitrate, and on grand master 2 extra attacks and plus hitrate. Combined with dual whield skill you can get a staggering amount of 6 attacks per round, your bladedancer becomes a weapon of mass destruction. Compared to this all other skills and magic school are just a joke in terms of damageoutput. You will need some skills/spells to progress like protection against status ailments, healing spells but for raw damage dagger and dual whield is greater then none.

Per levelup you get 4 attribute points you can allocate where you wish. For a seasoned rpg player it should be easy to get a deasant build. Melee 2 strength 1 perc, 1 vit, magic 1 magic, 1 vit 2 spirit in the beginning and 2 magic 1 vit 1 spirit later when you have enough manapoints (never).

I think the game release was rushed, the gameplay is boring and frustrating, the encounters are onesided against the player to the extreme, you cannot grind in a rpg!, the performance is bad even for the grafics and on excellent gaming rigs, the skills, classes, monster encounters are not balanced at all. I do not recommend this game.

Have a nice day

reviewText: I was going to recommend it, but the bugs (even two freakin' years after release) really annoyed me during the final boss fight with erebos. The game has that 90s nostalgia to it, and feels like the M&M classics (I've played MM3 through MMIX). However, it just didn't feel like it received the playtesting that it should have. Too many bugs. Combat movement a pain in the butt. Annoyingly long walks from location to location. Sometimes having to quit the middle of a dungeon and slow walk all the way back to town to restock. These aren't huge things to fix, but they're enough to really detract from gameplay. Disappointed.

reviewText:
Now I'll be completely honest here.
I've only played through the game once and I haven't touched the DLCs by any means.
Now I've played in the alpha/beta and I really enjoyed it, and when I first played the launched game, I really enjoyed it still, and even more.
I couldn't stop playing this game and I managed to finish almost all the quests in the game before finishing it.
And that's where the sour part comes.
This has to be the lamest, most disgustingly bad end boss ever made in history.

SPOILER START, for those who doesn't want their ending spoiled:

The final boss fight is basically:
1. Attack the boss.
2. Go to four rooms and kill the monsters there, and pick up a thing.
3. Go back to the center of the boss room and then plonk the thing into the thing.
4. Random flashlight of doom turns on and the boss dies.
5. You sit there thinking: Is that it?

SPOILER END.

But would I recommend this game?
Of course I would, it's a lovely and a great game, except for the final boss.
Now as I mentioned previously, I only played the game WITHOUT the DLCs.
I'd say fetch it if you like this kind of game, especially on discout sales.

reviewText:
Pains me to do so but Steam's inadequate yes/no recommendation system strikes again.  I'm not entirely sure of the development of this game but I suspect Ubisoft just threw these guys permission to use the license and very little in the way of funding.  The game feels extremely low budget.  Worse than some indie games.  Even looking past superficials like the unpolished graphics and lack of voice acting (things one would assume to be better with a AAA publisher) the mechanics are overly shallow such that most people will probably burn out on the excessive content due to tedium.

Melee is very basic with only one talent tree and limited attacks.  Range is pointless given the number of ambushes you face (and there's a penalty for shooting things at point blank/melee range).  The magic schools don't feel sufficiently different and mostly consist of nukes plus a couple of superfluous buff spells.  Yes, there are towns and quests and merchants and the occassional puzzle but all of it is very rudimentary.  Itemization is terrible consisting of a few hand placed relics with the rest being randomized Diablo-style crap.

MMX Legacy should be more polished and deeper than Grimrock (and not merely a turn-based alternative).  It isn't.  Moreoever it is arguably worse in some aspects like level design, character progression, itemization, etc.  You're better off playing the old Bard's Tale series as the graphics are only slightly worse but the gameplay is much deeper.   But that was funded by Interplay, right?  Well... this was ostensibly funded by Ubisoft.  Apparently not.  A shame.  Had they given this the funding they put in other iteration of the M&M series this would have been a fantastic game.  In its current condition it is mediocre at best.

reviewText:
Forget about the fail MM9, this is back to it's roots, back to MM6-8 goodness.
With better graphics, better skill system, better artworks and very interesting classes. The turn-based movement and fights system is interesting and works very well with the game, although you might need to get used to it nowadays. The story is good and carries you over a continent, several magical places and through at least two dreams/memories.

PROS:
- it's Might and Magic with it's old charm and playability
- classes are great, each one of them has a different skillset and you can spend hours optimising and synchronising parties to reach the best combo.
- lots of items, magic and world to discover
- it's fun

CONS:
- the turn-based/step moving may not be for everyone. Also, maps tend to be quite complex and the graphics around sometimes does not really reflect where you can and can not go, which will make you look more at the minimap, than the actual screen when moving. (Yon-chall forest, looking at you!)
- maps can not be scrolled. World map shows artwork without paths and local map shows only vicinity around you. What makes running to the other side of the map a bit more difficult, when trying to find things or people.
- the very last level in the last dungeon, where you'll meet the Big Bad of the story and he will attack you and disappear only to come back in a while and attack you again is more annoying than difficult.


TL;DR - back to oldschool" RPG game with very well made classes
date: skills and character development system. The story isn't bad either and the graphics is much better than oldschool games."

reviewText: I pre-purchased since I was a fan of the old school MM games. This game started out rough and only barely improved over the months. While it certainly has a bit of the old school feel it's also poorly designed and just not fun. I can understand wanting to recapture the nostalgia but in seeking to recreate the old classics they seemed to have mostly recreated all of the crap parts and left out much of the fun. This game is awful, especially at the price point they are asking and I would not recommend to anyone.

reviewText:
Sum it up:  If you are a die-hard old school MM fan, this is something that you long for.  If you are a RPG lover, stop by and look for a decent rpg, then you need to look for other better games.

I have played through the early access, and it was disappointing. I didn't make a comment because it was still beta phase. The full version has made tremendous improvments. For instance, the weapons won't break every second; you wouldn't fail to see your fingers at night due to poor lighting design. I see more barrels with more intereting content and better designed balance such as monster strength and potion pricing.

However, the core problems of the early access are not addressed.

First is no innovation at all. The game play and design is shockingly simplistic. You walk, see monsters, press 1144, then the monsters die. Class leveling is a straight one-way ticket. Monster fighting is the battle on who has more potions. This kind of game design maybe interesting 20 years ago. But to produce such a game at 21st century and charge people 25 dollars for it is simply not acceptable. There are some interesting puzzles, but not enough to make the game attractive.

Then here comes the cheapskate strategy of reduce, recycle and reuse. Ubisoft used this strategy on heroes VI, I still bear with it. However, what is this?  The monster appearance, NPCs, music and every other thing you see basically comes from dark messiah and heroesVI. Being of the same world Ashan, I guess some repetition is fine. But this games has gone too far. The worst part is these two games are of totally different age and types. Forcing elements of these two games into one feels like a big modded rpg from some random players community like WOG. Not to mention the texture and graphic is horrible. Some people say it doesn't work with 32bit OS, but my win8 64bit seems to have the same problem as well. In one word: they shouldn't charge 25USD just for a recycled product.

In conclusion, I am not against turn-based strategy games or rpg. But this game is nowhere on par with any decent modern day rpg. It is good for nostalgia. But if you are a real old school MMM fan you won't be bothered to read this review anyway. So I won't recommend to any general rpg players.

reviewText:
Might and Magic X - Legacy is manything but anything.

It is true, the game is still in development, the game appear quite short at the moment but progresses have been vastly made since day 1 pre release and new updates keep coming up. It is not super fast but they keep coming up and considering the team is not huge then I tip my hat for their tremendous effort.

This game is an interesting mix and remix of old days M&M and tile RPG mixed in our todays 3D engine capabilities.
The game sticks well to M&M while trying to keep it cohesive and loose at the same time.
The dev have so far been doing a real good job and I invite M&M lovers and new comers to this game for cozy days or during work lunch time for peaceful and definitely transporting time.

Also as a good note, users can mod for the game and it is not too complicated with the use of Unity.

reviewText:
I was looking forward to this. I have warm, fuzzy memories of Might and Magic VI, it was the first game that introduced me to generic fantasy and sword and sorcery. I was thrilled to see a non-heroes M&M title.
This game is a complete disappointment for me. I came expecting to enjoy more of the bliss that VI-III and left sad and with less money.

The game does not have paper doll inventories, does not have free movement, and didn't let me push a snake dude off a cliff with a wind spell.

It is not worth my time, and if you wanted to experience what were objectively the best titles in the classic M&M series this game is not worth yours either.

Probably pretty ok if you like the REALLY old ones, though.

reviewText:
Short verdict: It is a good old school RGP improved by some of today’s standards and I would rate it 8/10

Good:
- Great character/skill system with many options
- Highly motivating due to tough enemies and frequent level ups
- Great feeling of getting stronger over time (enemies don’t level up)
- Lots of different items to loot
- Long playtime (at least 60 hours)
- Comfortable automap

Mixed:
- Fights can be really hard in early game (and depend on luck because of critical hit chances on crucial characters/enemies)
- No group formation (but other crowd control possibilities)
- No respawning enemies means no grinding possible
- At a certain point (near the end) the fights get too easy and repetitive
- Much backtracking
- Much higher reward for quests (xp) and boss fights (loot) compared to regular fights
- 2 passive companions kind of expand the party to 6 characters
- Graphics are mediocre but good enough to enjoy the game

Bad:
- Unclear dead ends because some locations/characters/items are available but can’t be used because you don't have the needed characters in your party
- Quest progress might get blocked by having no room for a needed companion
- Still some bugs (huge lags while moving is the only problem that happens a lot)
- You can't scroll the minimap

Details:
Think of a mixture of Legend of Grimrock and Wizardry8 (there might be better comparisons but those games come to my mind).
At first glance it looks like another LoG because of the tile based movement. But combat rather feels like Wizardry 8 since it is fully turn based so no moving/strafing around and wild clicking like in LoG.
What is really different and could be seen as flaw is that it doesn't use any group formation. I really had to get used to this as I clearly expected to be able to place my weak characters in the back so that they won't get hit but in fact the whole group (and also a certain amount of enemies can) share 1 tile. But the game uses other features to circumvent this flaw". Every character can easily (1 skill point) learn a skill that if he uses it for attacking lets the enemy counterattack this character the next round. So you have to use this special attack for your fighter/high defense/hitpoints characters to draw the attacks of enemies away from your mages/rangers. The problem with this is that you often face more than 1 (or 2) enemies at a time
date: some enemies are simply immune to that kind of taunt and strong enemies also often use group attacks that harm every member so even when using that skill the weak characters die/fall unconscious more often than your "front" warriors which really can be annoying. Falling unconscious only means losing the experience points from any enemies that are killed during that state while dead characters can only be revived with high level skills or in town. The fighting in general can be very tough. You often stumble over enemies that easily wipe your party. But this also is one of the best parts of that game - at least for me. It is highly motivating to encounter enemies you can't defeat yet but knowing that you will defeat them when you come back later. I love RPGs that handle it this way. Another thing I like is that enemies don't respawn. When you clear an area it stays cleared.\nAlthough I think that the fights are tougher than e.g. in LoG
recommended: the game is quite forgiving since you can easily quicksave/reload (not during fight though). Also it is much more convenient to play thanks to the excellent automap. The story of the game is mediocre I think and also there are no great characters that kept me engaged. But what keeps me motivated is the constant feel of reward because you level up quite often and always get attribute and skill points to distribute. Once you reach a new skill level (novice
hoursPlayed: expert
voteText: master
helpfulPercent: grand master) you need to find the correct trainer so that you can finally unlock the benefit of that skill rank. So the game always keeps you going (something e.g. Wasteland 2 lacks of). What greatly adds to the motivation is an item system comparable with diablo. So there are tons of items to find that always are a little better than the one you already own. There are green items with 1 magic attribute
votesHelpful: blue with 2 and yellow (relics) that get up to 4 attributes but need to gain experience first. Those also don't need to be repaired - correct
votesTotal:
items get worn over time and need to be repaired to restore their full potential. But this happens quite slowly and most of the time you found better gear already before you have to repair the old one.

You can argue about if fights are rewarding enough though. You gain much more experience by completing quests and also the loot of the standard fights consists of standard (random?) items like potions or mostly useless gear. So only boss fights drop something special but most stuff can be found in chests (which are often hidden though).
Secrets are also discussworthy. You don't have to search every wall for that special mark you have to click like in LoG but instead you either need to cast a spell that wears off after 50+ turns (depends on magic skill) and marks secrets or you need the correct companion to find secrets. Companions are also a neat idea. You can have up to 2 join and they give some special bonus to the party like better prices at the merchant or a healing now and then. Most of them need to be paid though and some quests let you have join one. There is one annoying problem with the companions. There are some that join for quests and you can't remove them from your party until the quest is solved. Also there is a horse as companion that doubles your inventory which is very important - at least for hoarders like me. To be honest you don't need it and will have enough gold to buy anything by the mid of the game anyway... But I ended up having the horse and a quest guy that needed to go to a special place I could not yet reach and the result was that I was blocked in the main quest until I got rid of lots of stuff and my horse to be able to continue.
So back to the secrets: Once you found a secret you still have to decide which character of your group wants to try to "use" it. Different secrets make different checks for might
votesFunny:
magic or perception (I think). You can either learn the different signs or just reload if it didn't work (the char will fall unconscious if he fails). The same can be sad about the barrels that can be found everywhere. They contain a liquid with different colors and every colour stands for a stat that increases permanently when drinking the liquid. So it is the basic functionality of permanent +1 to some stat that you know from other modern RPGs where you have to collect flowers or similar stuff and this also adds some motivation.

I didn't mention the biggest flaw in my eyes yet: You will stumble across certain quest items/characters/locations that won't do anything because they are only available for certain characters and you can't have all of them in your party. That is some really bad design here because you end up confused and don't know if you are missing something or if it is just not possible to do something. I ended up checking forums whenever I was uncertain if I am blind...
Also I should mention that large parts of the map are blocked as long as you didn't get certain "skills" that let you pass through. I think that mechanic is ok
commentsCount: it only causes much backtracking to locations you couldn't visit earlier. It is only really annoying when such a block is deep within a dungeon. You can mark such spots on the worldmap so at least they are easy to find later (the map can become clustered with notes though).\n\nSo in the end I had a mixed experience. Most hours were great fun and I couldn't stop. Some were quite annoying and in the end I didn't finish the game because it was too easy and I already got most of the rewards/unlocks/max skills I was playing for."

reviewText:
Long story short: If you are looking for a Legend of Grimrock experience: Do not buy this game! You will end up being disappointed.

Plot: Not terrible but nothing we haven't seen before
Characters: In one word: Boring
Gameplay: Take Legend of Grimrocks combat. Make it turn-based. Make ranged combat much less viable. Remove kiting.
No traps, no hidden treasures and no puzzles
Character Customization: Very simple
Soundtrack: Average
Design: Character/Creature models aren't bad, but still far from decent. Cities, dungeons and the overworld are bland and uninspired. Lighting effects are nonexistent

Conclusion:
Legend of Grimrock was an above average rpg. So what do you consider a game that is less than that?

reviewText:
I'm going to slog through this game anyway out of dedication to the series, but honestly... it's pretty bad. If you've ever played any of the original Might & Magic games and were excited to play the much-hyped revamp... well, that's too bad, because there isn't really anything they have in common with them aside from some loose superficiality.


Character creation:
There really isn't any. This may seem surprising at the outset -- after all, hasn't this kind of always been a hallmark of the entire series? Tweak your character and your party (because, hey, who wants the default party, right?) and test your theories to see if it's survivable. Sometimes you may not even find out until halfway through the game. Balance your party with early, mid, and late-game classes, and grind your way up to success, right?

Well.. no. There are four races, and each race has three classes (a 'might' class, a 'magic' class, and a hybrid class). Each one gets one or two special abilities once they're promoted (like MM6), and also like MM6, you have to receive 'training' to go from novice to expert to master to grandmaster in your skills. Like MM6, these trainers are also spread all throughout the world, and you have to learn where they are (or read a spoiler). Your class choice feels almost entirely flavourless, and pretty much only determines what skills you can raise to what caps (and at times, what skills you can even learn at all). Also, you only get four party members.


Control and feel:
The game is on a grid, like Xeen-style era of Might & Magic, and things only move when you do. Monsters don't patrol, however, and unless they 'see' you, they won't go anywhere. When they do see you, the 'danger' light turns hostile, and they will proceed to chase you... forever. You cannot outrun monsters or get them to some kind of 'tether' range, so if you step into the wrong area, your only option is to reload the game. There is no fleeing.

NPCs are also like the Xeen era of M&M, in the sense that they appear to only be found in towns (or in map objects on the main map), and do not move. They CAN be found standing around in the game world in towns, but do not actually move. The ones that you can't talk to (which is most of them) do, however, tend to say one of possibly four or five quipped lines, which will replay, endlessly, every time you are standing near them. This is also true of 'environment' sound effects like mumbling, people shuffling things, hammers on anvils, etc. It is generally one sound that loops forever until you step away.


UI:
The UI is pretty minimal, which is OK. There is an 'action bar', akin to the one on most MMOs, with 10 slots that you can set for each of your 4 party members. Frequently, however (particularly on a mage), you will have to go to your skill book and manually cast from there, as it's simply not feasable to have everything you need on the bar. Not a big deal; it's split up intelligently.

There is a minimap, which autorecords your progress on a gridded map. Unfortunately, however, you can not scroll this map even when you make it larger, so if you're looking for somewhere that's off the side of the enlarged map, too bad.


Gameplay:
There aren't terribly many spells per spell 'level' per school, but there are a lot of schools, which means there's still a hefty amount of spells. Unlike previous games in the series, there are not 'master' or 'grandmaster' schools of each element, there are simply libraries in each town that have all the spells and you pick from there.

Weapons and armour can break (this appears to be random chance -- I had a new item I just picked up break in a second combat, and a weapon I used the entire game until then -- 17 hours in -- never break), which degrades their stats until you go to town to repair it. There is no 'mobile repair' that I've encountered yet, though perhaps there is a spell for it that I'm unaware of.

Like previous Might and Magic games, you can have two 'hirelings' (sometimes one or both may be a mandatory 'quest' hireling), but these hirelings do not participate in combat as they did in the later versions -- they are back to simply providing an auxiliary benefit for a small percentage cut of your gold and a hiring fee.

There is no grinding, not because grinding is not necessary, but because monsters do not respawn. Ever. If you have killed a monster, it is permanently gone. This means that there is a *fixed* finite level of gold and loot in the game, and even things like the well
date: it'll respawn in a few months" option in previous iterations of the series is gone.\n\nThere is no party formation -- each spot in the party lineup is equal
recommended: and it doesn't matter if you get flanked or attacked from behind. Everything does the same damage with the same random odds of it hitting someone as anything else.\n\nLike some later M&M games

Camping cannot be interrupted.\n\nAreas are 'gated' by progress -- did you put points into 'shield' to get it to expert level (the first tier past the starting one) so you can have that extra edge on the boss you're fighting in the beginning? reviewText:
Might and Magic X is an ok game that falls short of pretty much all its successors (the word is correct, as technically, MMX is supposed to be something like MM 5.5, hence why you get MM6 to complement it), even the mediocre Might and Magic 9. As if to add insult to injury, UbiSoft gives us the extremely good MM6 as a part of the deal as if to tell you - here, this is what Might and Magic 6 represented - tons of spells, water walking, flight, exploration, the ability to look under every nook and cranny and actually be rewarded for it. Might and Magic 6-8 were the golden years of the franchise, and every game brought the lineage to new hights. Then came MM9 which pretty much destroyed all the exploration, but added new 3D engine and interesting locales with roughly as much freedom as its forefathers.

And now, as a slap in the face comes MMX Legacy with its MM6 bonus. Let's compare the two:
1. Movement.
1.1. MM6 has free movement, turning, water walking, flight, strategic positioning even while entering combat AND during combat.
1.2. MMX is rigid as hell. You are forced into a square grid which not only makes the whole movement experince choppy and unpleasant, but also forces you to turn around just as choppily just to see if you haven't missed anything. Why were can't I enter water squares without having a certain god's blessing? Did people simply forget what a Water Walk spell is?
2. Combat.
2.1. MM6 has the best of both systems - turn based combat and real time combat. Turn based combat works like MMX, while in real time you could fly, play to the enemies' disadvantages (like use Water Walk and escpe on water while range attacking the enemies). It was liberating as hell and actually encouraged strategic thinking.
2.2. MMX combat is rigid and there is little need for strategy. Battles are best won if you can put yourself in a corner or a corridor so that only a few enemies at a time have the opportunity to attack you, while you pick them off easily as the others simply wait dumbly for their turns to enter your killzone. And people said that flying and water walking in MM6-8 was exploiting the system...
3. Exploration.
3.1. MM6 encouraged exploration on any level and at any time and actually rewarded you for it. And to prove that, the devs actually put a flight scroll in your starting city, so that you can go and explore. Opening every inch of a map in MM6 is exciting and rewards you with secret islands off the coast that have money or chests lying around, craters in mountains with obelisks, chests, and other rewards. I even found extremely rare items like artifacts and relics in such chests! Even if you encounter difficullt enemies (like even dragons or titans), you have a chance to fly or teleport away to escape and come back later.
3.2. MMX offers little in terms of exploration, mainly because everything is a corridor - and even if you get adventurous and press on, you get punished by it, because you encounter very difficult enemies and have little or no chance against them, which results in death. Artifacts and Relics are found in specific location, and up until now with 2 running play-throughs with 2 different groups, I found the same artifacts in the very same spots in the very sam dungeons. YAY!
4. Equipment.
4.1. MM6 has tons of gear diversity. You would just bite your nails before opening a chest or looting a body, looking at that hotbar right above your characters. Ding... You find 24 gold and an item (Axe)! - hell yeah, my guy needs a new one, is it better? Ding... You found 1096 gold and an item (Relic)! OH YEAH!!! What does it do? Can I even identify it? Can any of guys use it? OH it's a ring, all of my guys can use rings, but I don't know what it does! Screw that, I am porting to town to find out! This nailbiting, mouthwatering experience is very much gone in MMX.
4.2. MMX has a very rigid gear system. 90% of the time I have been finding better stuff in shops than in chests or the bodies of slain enemies. If you want to make a specific character build, you have to rely on the shops in the various cities. And yeah, just go to that same dungeon to get your artifact at the end. YAY...
5. Characters and classes.
MMX does have more diversity in Race/Class creation than MM6 (12 vs 9), but one can't escape the feeling that many of those race/class combos play and feel the same. They also reuse the MM6 system of making specialized fighters & casters, and then add hybrids of both classes. So in essense, you have 4 warrior classes, 4 Hybrid classes and 4 Caster classes. One nukes more, another heals more. One gets an extra attack, the other is better protected. Hybrids can really accomplish a lot and supplement your party well. A touch and go system, really...
In MM6 you had limitations - you Cleric was a poor fighter, but could heal and learn Light/Dark Magic and become an even better healer, buffer, or nuker. Your Knight could wear the best armor and hit like a ten ton truck, and get more attacks per turn. Your Paladin (the Knight/Cleric combo) could hit and heal, but had no access to the best healing & buffing spells from the light tree.
Here, you get a Crusader with Lay on Hands for max heals at any given time at the cost of all your mana who can learn Grandmaster Light Magic (cool heals/buffs), Grandmaster Sword (good fighter), Grandmaster Heavy (well protected), Grandmaster Arcane (Lots of magic resistance). Why not have a few of those in your party, then? IMO, Crusaders very much break the game.

6. To conclude: please don't get me started on the UDONTPLAY 3rd party DRM...

EDIT: As I put it in the comment: That being said, I am a completionist and I will still finish the game. I, however, cannot shake the feeling that it is inferior to all others though. It is like returning to the dark times before your golden age just for the sake of nostalgia.

In short, I would recommend that you buy an MM6-8 bundle and immerse yourself in the 3D-ish world of those games. Explore, fly, walk on water, steal stuff and have fun. Don't be swayed by this Grimrock-style Might and Magic game just because of the Might and Magic in it like I was...

reviewText:
It's a mixed bag really, for die hard fans of the series it's probably enough to keep you going right to the end just to see the familiar characters / monsters.

However it's biggest problem is what I would call it's tipping point, at one stage you realize that you can pretty much faceroll any encounter and should probably just cut to the chase and head on to the final battle, which is not very enjoyable, despite it having a challenging and satisfying start to the adventure.

Further dismay awaits in what can only be described as 'painful' voice acting, even the automatic checkouts at Tesco have more passion :-P

reviewText:
Long story short: If you are looking for a Legend of Grimrock experience: Do not buy this game! You will end up being disappointed.

Plot: Not terrible but nothing we haven't seen before
Characters: In one word: Boring
Gameplay: Take Legend of Grimrocks combat. Make it turn-based. Make ranged combat much less viable. Remove kiting.
No traps, no hidden treasures and no puzzles
Character Customization: Very simple
Soundtrack: Average
Design: Character/Creature models aren't bad, but still far from decent. Cities, dungeons and the overworld are bland and uninspired. Lighting effects are nonexistent

Conclusion:
Legend of Grimrock was an above average rpg. So what do you consider a game that is less than that?

reviewText:
Might and Magic X is an ok game that falls short of pretty much all its successors (the word is correct, as technically, MMX is supposed to be something like MM 5.5, hence why you get MM6 to complement it), even the mediocre Might and Magic 9. As if to add insult to injury, UbiSoft gives us the extremely good MM6 as a part of the deal as if to tell you - here, this is what Might and Magic 6 represented - tons of spells, water walking, flight, exploration, the ability to look under every nook and cranny and actually be rewarded for it. Might and Magic 6-8 were the golden years of the franchise, and every game brought the lineage to new hights. Then came MM9 which pretty much destroyed all the exploration, but added new 3D engine and interesting locales with roughly as much freedom as its forefathers.

And now, as a slap in the face comes MMX Legacy with its MM6 bonus. Let's compare the two:
1. Movement.
1.1. MM6 has free movement, turning, water walking, flight, strategic positioning even while entering combat AND during combat.
1.2. MMX is rigid as hell. You are forced into a square grid which not only makes the whole movement experince choppy and unpleasant, but also forces you to turn around just as choppily just to see if you haven't missed anything. Why were can't I enter water squares without having a certain god's blessing? Did people simply forget what a Water Walk spell is?
2. Combat.
2.1. MM6 has the best of both systems - turn based combat and real time combat. Turn based combat works like MMX, while in real time you could fly, play to the enemies' disadvantages (like use Water Walk and escpe on water while range attacking the enemies). It was liberating as hell and actually encouraged strategic thinking.
2.2. MMX combat is rigid and there is little need for strategy. Battles are best won if you can put yourself in a corner or a corridor so that only a few enemies at a time have the opportunity to attack you, while you pick them off easily as the others simply wait dumbly for their turns to enter your killzone. And people said that flying and water walking in MM6-8 was exploiting the system...
3. Exploration.
3.1. MM6 encouraged exploration on any level and at any time and actually rewarded you for it. And to prove that, the devs actually put a flight scroll in your starting city, so that you can go and explore. Opening every inch of a map in MM6 is exciting and rewards you with secret islands off the coast that have money or chests lying around, craters in mountains with obelisks, chests, and other rewards. I even found extremely rare items like artifacts and relics in such chests! Even if you encounter difficullt enemies (like even dragons or titans), you have a chance to fly or teleport away to escape and come back later.
3.2. MMX offers little in terms of exploration, mainly because everything is a corridor - and even if you get adventurous and press on, you get punished by it, because you encounter very difficult enemies and have little or no chance against them, which results in death. Artifacts and Relics are found in specific location, and up until now with 2 running play-throughs with 2 different groups, I found the same artifacts in the very same spots in the very sam dungeons. YAY!
4. Equipment.
4.1. MM6 has tons of gear diversity. You would just bite your nails before opening a chest or looting a body, looking at that hotbar right above your characters. Ding... You find 24 gold and an item (Axe)! - hell yeah, my guy needs a new one, is it better? Ding... You found 1096 gold and an item (Relic)! OH YEAH!!! What does it do? Can I even identify it? Can any of guys use it? OH it's a ring, all of my guys can use rings, but I don't know what it does! Screw that, I am porting to town to find out! This nailbiting, mouthwatering experience is very much gone in MMX.
4.2. MMX has a very rigid gear system. 90% of the time I have been finding better stuff in shops than in chests or the bodies of slain enemies. If you want to make a specific character build, you have to rely on the shops in the various cities. And yeah, just go to that same dungeon to get your artifact at the end. YAY...
5. Characters and classes.
MMX does have more diversity in Race/Class creation than MM6 (12 vs 9), but one can't escape the feeling that many of those race/class combos play and feel the same. They also reuse the MM6 system of making specialized fighters & casters, and then add hybrids of both classes. So in essense, you have 4 warrior classes, 4 Hybrid classes and 4 Caster classes. One nukes more, another heals more. One gets an extra attack, the other is better protected. Hybrids can really accomplish a lot and supplement your party well. A touch and go system, really...
In MM6 you had limitations - you Cleric was a poor fighter, but could heal and learn Light/Dark Magic and become an even better healer, buffer, or nuker. Your Knight could wear the best armor and hit like a ten ton truck, and get more attacks per turn. Your Paladin (the Knight/Cleric combo) could hit and heal, but had no access to the best healing & buffing spells from the light tree.
Here, you get a Crusader with Lay on Hands for max heals at any given time at the cost of all your mana who can learn Grandmaster Light Magic (cool heals/buffs), Grandmaster Sword (good fighter), Grandmaster Heavy (well protected), Grandmaster Arcane (Lots of magic resistance). Why not have a few of those in your party, then? IMO, Crusaders very much break the game.

6. To conclude: please don't get me started on the UDONTPLAY 3rd party DRM...

EDIT: As I put it in the comment: That being said, I am a completionist and I will still finish the game. I, however, cannot shake the feeling that it is inferior to all others though. It is like returning to the dark times before your golden age just for the sake of nostalgia.

In short, I would recommend that you buy an MM6-8 bundle and immerse yourself in the 3D-ish world of those games. Explore, fly, walk on water, steal stuff and have fun. Don't be swayed by this Grimrock-style Might and Magic game just because of the Might and Magic in it like I was...

reviewText:
TL;DR:  You are better of with the Legend of Grimrock I and II.  Uplay DRM sucks. Ubisoft. Go ♥♥♥♥ yourselves.

History:
My first Might and Magic game was Might and Magic 3, on DOS.
I bought this due to Nostalgia.

UPLAY's DRM:
What's the difference between a virus and Uplay? A virus works.
Seriously. It's more like UPRAY the damn thing works.
Now I know why their logo looks like a sphincter, because I got ♥♥♥♥ed in the ♥♥♥.
They changed my ubi.com account to a uplay because '♥♥♥♥ you' that's why. But, then there was a password breach.
Now. I can't log into my other account. 'Forget Password' is a button that does nothing.   ...NOTHING!
When creating another account in-game it says Ubisoft's servers are down.
Ubisoft servers seem to go down more often than a two dollar hooker.
Yet, I was able to create an account on their webpage.
Why does it work on the website but not in-game? Because '♥♥♥♥ you', that's why.
Seriously ♥♥♥♥ YOU Ubisoft. I only bought this POS for nostalgia (and regretted it 20 minutes later). If you're an Ubisoft executive, you should go castrate yourself. You're too stupid to breed.

DISCLAIMER:
The 40 minutes of trying to bypass the UPLAY DRM just to play the damn game somewhat tarnished my feelings towards the rest of the game.

THE STORY:
Oh for ♥♥♥♥ sake. This is a perfect example of how NOT to do an intro.
You get this amazing rambling piece of ♥♥♥♥, while this wonderfully rendered woman reads a book.  Exciting? No. It's like Grandpa Simpson...tons of references, and naming of locations I have no clue about.
Imagine the fantasy version of this:

We can't bust heads like we used to

reviewText:
Once again dungeon RPG worth to play.
I have found several aspects of the game pretty good, perfect legacy and tribute to MaM world.

Enemies are not plenty like in MaM to Day of Destroyer, but more difficult to kill.
Level cap is lower than in previous games.
Outside locations? well one location....I could imagine more dungeons too.
Movement only in right angles - for me a little setback.
Promotions and skills are pretty same, no training center though and fewer skill points.
You can complete promotion quest unless you have that class.
Missing town portal spell.
Only a straightforward storyline...
Sometimes sluggish graphical performance, especially in the forest...

reviewText:
Not sure why this game gets so much hate, I'm having loads of fun with it so far.

Yes it's a bit buggy and could have done with more polish, yues uplay is bloody annoying, but it has greta music, atmosphere, and is just a decent dungeon crawler.

Also, if you think that by choosing not to buy the game due to uplay that you'll make Ubisoft stop using it then think again. All you do is hurt the devs by not buying this because of uplay, Ubisoft don't care, they'll use uplay regardless of whether people buy their games or not.

But to clarify this game doesn't need 'always on' uplay drm, which is what steam is, it just requires a single activation via uplay, after that you can go offline.

So overall, decent dungeon crawler, I would recommend it.

reviewText:
Pros:

- Lots of spells, weapons, armor, and items to satisfy your cravings for treasure.
- Engaging and clever puzzles.
- Tactical combat that is easy to pick up, but still provides a challenge.
- Solid story with characters Might & Magic fans may find familiar.
- Simplified level system from previous games.

Cons:

- uPlay required (They do give you some extras when you use uPlay units though. I don't like it, but at least they give you some nice extras for it).
- Slow to load, some objects don't appear properly (several shrubs appeared in the middle of a fight where there were no shrubs/foliage at first a couple times. Not a deal breaker, just a little weird).
- There is a glitch that corrupts your save file (If this happens, don't erase your old game! Start a new one and enter the first dungeon. Then, when the game autosaves when you've entered, load your old game!)
- Grid movement system isn't for everybody (though the old free movement system from 6,7, & 8 was a little wonky, so do what you like).

All in all, highly recommended.

reviewText: This game is modeled after Might and Magic 1-5, in the sense that it takes place on a grid and is entirely turn-based.  It has a lot of what made the old might and magic games good to great, but you'll definitely notice some streamlining and trimming of features.  All character skills have shifted towards combat, and you won't reach a point where you get a forester or mountaineer perk that lets you pass through impassible terrain.  Regardless, fans of the series will enjoy a bit tighter of a Might and Magic experience.. and those unfamiliar with the series will be in for some new challenges and possible frustration.  Playing on Warrior difficulty, there were some definitely challenging moments, but I managed to make it through despite picking sub-optimal character classes.\n\nAt the end of the day, it was a good solid dungeon crawl with an old-school feel.  Recommended for someone who wants a dungeon crawl with the occasional puzzle.

reviewText:
TL:DR - This is not a faithful recreation at all. The clostest thing you get is the freedom to make your own party of characters and even this is very limited. Besides that, you are moving along with a grid-based world, permentally stuck in turn-based combat. In a world that punishes exploration.

===Combat===
Combat is all turn-based. If you and an enemy are right next to each other, you cannot move. This means that once you engage in combat, You're stuck. No leaving. No retreating. And this becomes a serious problem when you start to explore. You will go to areas that you are not prepared for. And You will get into combat with things you cannot fight. And You can't run. You will die... For exploring... In an open world RPG that encourages you to explore. The previous might and magic games have made it possible. But the problem is the addition of this grid based combat/exploration. In previous games, you could go to an impossible difficulty area, and the first attack kills a party member. You turn, and run away. Maybe lose another party member to a stray shot. But you can still run away and escape. Nothing bound you, like a grid does here. If an enemy engages you in melee combat, you're stuck exchanging blows. No smart manuvering or tactical fighting like in previous games or in legend of grimmock.... No, make your attacks, take your blows, repeat until you or the enemy is dead.

===Exploration===
As mentioned previously, you are punished for exploring if you happen to end up in an area you cannot fight in. You have to use that quick save... Alot. Its not even fun to explore. Everything is grid based. So you will find boundaries, and areas that look like you can go through but you can't because the grid says you can't go here. It's a massive step down from the previous games where you could scale mountions, fly above and look at the whole world, or jump into the water and risk drowning to discover cool treasures. Heck, it was rewarding to go exploring in areas, that your party wasn't prepared for, to grab some of the loot there. None of that in this game.

reviewText: I have been a fan of the series since the fifth game, but this one feels like Ubi just felt like throwing sand in the eyes of fans. The graphics are decent, but the game is buggy, the combat is cumbersome and very unfair (the enemies can move when in melee, but you can't), and the characters aren't interesting at all. I'm not just talking about the NPCs, but the ones in your party are also very dull cardboard cutouts and incredibly repetitive in what they say (they also announce warnings for no reason whatsoever). reviewText:
I strongly recommend this title to players who remember the golden age of cRPGs. This may not be everyone's cup of tea but if you like a good old-fashioned dungeon crawl, no other modern titles can touch this.

Graphics: The graphics are good but the performance is a bit spotty. Still, if you ever wanted to try an old school dungeon crawler but were put off by the graphics, this will help you get into them.

Sound: The sound is wonderful. The music, the voices, the effects, etc all work well.

Story: These are not the kinds of games you play for story purposes. Still, if you bother to read all the text, there is a decent story there. There are even texts you can find to figure out the back story of the world or characters.

Gameplay: This is where the game scores the highest marks. There are 4 races with 3 classes per race. You assemble a team of 4 from those choices. This makes the game immensely replayable. I have just finished the second act and am already planning my Hard mode playthrough.

Also, the game has many nice touches. It has mechanics to limit rest abuse. Potion overuse is limited by hefty potion costs. Over-levelling is slightly limited by the lack of respawns.

Overally, I love this game. It was a great surprise.

reviewText:
As a game itself this is a great title in the series.  As an installation I'm afraid I am not very satifsfied.  The game does not run direct from Steam but from Ubisoft meaning I had to make yet another account for yet another software company.  This was not apparent upon purchase at the time either.

I can no longer access this Ubisoft account and so can not play the game.  If you make a new account the CD code you get upon purchse will no longer work and so I am stuffed, even after reinstalling the game from Steam.

I wouldn't have been so frustrated with the program were it not for the fact that game itself was rather good.

Not reccommended due to 3rd party requirements I'm afraid.  And if you search for help or support you will find NONE at all, apart from a few notes about the CD code basically telling you that you're screwed...

reviewText:
It is not hard core enough to be the greatest chapter of Might&Magic, yet too hard core to be a master piece.

Why? A game requires players do their home works...all kind of it...put notes on map, scheduel carefully on their finance, spells, party organizing... etc.. And we haven't touched combat yet.

Non-escaping, D&D encounter, Geez! Im both thrilled and damned.

Look, I don't want to save before each combat, but I put so much effert into my party, I can't just let them die and reroll the whole game again!

strategic wise, there are too many ambushes. Players are pretty much conered most of time.

Though it reminds me the old school M&M... we have to move forward around the inconvinient part...

If designers expect players plan their own adventure, then make the game more open and allow more mistakes.

The game is not hard, it is just unfriendly. But it was done so as intended. Therefore developer is to be blamed.

It has the potential to be as great as Skyrim with such a completed resourceful world and mechanism.

However, the playing through in an Open world with a Linear and steep learning curse is just sad.

The execution just won't do.

However,
I still recommend this game because it isn't easy to find this style anymore, it is as rare as you can get.

reviewText:
Very fun game and I'd recommend it, especially on sale where it's a steal.  One of those few games that I played obsessively to completion (I usually flit around between games as I own so many and have tons installed, and it's rare that something grips me enough to cause me to focus).

The visuals never looked as good for me as they do in the screenshots here and I have a beastly computer - so maybe I was missing something (and usually the first thing I do in any game is check settings/options).

The game for all its glory has some of the longest and load times and most pitiful performance of any game I've ever experienced.  It's a testament to how good the game itself is that one can put up with the horrid technical implementation of this game.  I mean, it's a turn based RPG with decent for the style graphics, and there's no execuse for how crappy the game performs when you're out and about in the world, or the insanely long loading times.  You would almost have to intentionally code something intentionally poorly to reach these lows and the fact that zero attempt was ever made to patch in optimization is pretty sad.

reviewText: Pretty much just a stright up dungeon crawl RPG. You get to design 4 characters and customize them, which is in tradition with the old school Might and Magic games. reviewText:
Positives:
If you are feeling nostalgic for old school Might and Magic, this is a great game for you!
The game is very pretty, which is one of the jarring things about trying to play the old games for me.
At low levels, I had a lot of fun.

Negatives:
Still some annoying bugs.
Has the most outdated, annoying, frustrating, enraging and overall pisser of a game mechanic in the form of artificial limitations on your characters skillsets. Why can't I have a Freemage with Fire Magic at grandmaster? When I finally noticed I would not be able to achieve my planned skill and spell build I was a bit ticked. It made me nostalgic, indeed.... for the modern games that give me the freedom to build my character the way I want it.

Lagging.  (oh come on, the textures look like a PS1 game!!)
Goblin attacks.
Miss.
Block.
Miss.
Block.
Miss.
Block.
Miss.
Block.
Drink Mana Potion
Miss.
Block.
Miss.
Miss.
Miss.
Miss.
Miss.
Goblin hits you for 34 damage, you are unconscious.
Goblin hits you for 62 damage, you are dead.
Loading.
Loading.
Loading....
....

There are so many reasons to hate this, but underneath all of them is an outstanding game.  I just wish it was a smoother experience to get to the wonderful gameplay.  The grid map and movement is great, the map looks like one you might do with graph paper as you're playing a game, I dig it.  The enemies are classic fantasy and are a good fight until they become extinct and you're left with an empty map looking for the next unlockable section.  I really like that you can play entirely with a keyboard, gives my mouse/drawing hand a much needed break.  There are 4 races, with a total of 12 advanced classes.  No customization, which is ok here, but they only give you four portraits to choose from for each race, and that includes male and female, so it's really just the dark haired male/female, or the light haired male/female.  Interestingly you can choose all four of your party members with the same race/class/skills/portrait if you choose and have a quadruplet party.  But this is a solid RPG at its core.  There are two difficulties, and I'm trying to complete it on hard without looking up anything online, and will update this review once I've gotten there.

reviewText:
As a fan of the later Might and Magic (basically 7 and 8) this game is an utter disappointment.

This game is built around die and retrying to a scary level. You basically go to any area possible, get killed by the first mob or barely survive, then have to find the next area where you might possibly be able to advance.
Difficulty spikes evenly at moments, for example you get a few solitary mobs for a while and then a pack of 2 and an elite with them which makes the fight annoyingly hard early on.
Boss fights are also unbalanced. You might be able to complete their dungeon without pain, and still have to keep away from them,  go somewhere else leveling and getting better equipment, then come back for a hard fight.
The mix of multiple mob levels in a single dungeon is also a pain as you are always saving before taking a step in another direction (level 10 in a area and level 15+ not far from it depending on another quest).

I don't like the map designs, with at times just annoying path blockers, put there for no apparent reason, and towns are too big (while it makes for a real town for a grid based game it makes it a labor to travel the streets).
Overall design quality isn't really good and game is unoptimized. Running into the forest and jungle kills FPS to a stop.

Story wise you get a common story which is neither good nor bad per se.
Classes are limited and some are apparently almost useless, like the defender which sacrifices damage for a shield but can't use his tanking skills on any boss and a number of mobs
Bug wise I only had a inconvenience with sound, after 8 hours of game time the combat music wouldn't stop but would be piled upon the last one after each new fight. Reloading or changing map restores the usual sound until the next fight (which isn't hard as you always reload anyway).

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game.
I saw alot of negative reviews on this and went to write a positive review because I was enjoying it.
The thing is the more I played it and looked for good things to say the more I find reasons why you shouldn't buy it.

Its a dungeon crawler with no random encounters; just scripted battles.
The world is displayed as open but plays as if it is on rails.

The writing so far is boiler -plate and bland.

The production values are terrible, graphics and sounds far below expections, yet despite the low quality of these the loading time are many and long.

The quests are handly orginal, the race and class choices are lets face is laughable.

As much and I keenly want to recommend this game you are far better off spending your money on legend of grimrock or paper sorcerer.

I wanted to enjoy this game and played it far long than I should hoping I would but the fact is it's a waste of your money when there are far worthier games out there.

And that is ignoring the plague on humanity that is ubisoft's DRM which just terrible.

reviewText:
Initially I had high hopes for MMX as I've been a long time fan of the series since the early 90s, but MMX makes me question the developers ideas because they simply do not work period.  Some of the worst aspects are combat related, such as being locked into combat and no monsters are in the local area, a bug that STILL has not been fixed, this particular bug occurs because of the ridiculously decision to make the combat turn based, where as the previous games was all psedo-turn based meaning you could move your party/pause the game and attack.   MMx locks you into a fight to the death once monsters reach a certain distance from your character, unfortunately I've had this bug out far too many times forcing a reload to a previous point to fix - not to mention this particular type of combat also punishes the players rather harshly against ranged monsters, because you sometimes can't move into melee range!! Absurd but true!!  Honestly - the person who thought up this mechanic should be fired because its one of the serious gamebreaking issues MMx has.

If your a veteran of the MM series, you'll know that skill points are valuable but in previous games you had somewhat leeway into making some mistakes with your builds, MMx forces you into very specific builds and characters classes otherwise you could literally become stuck in game without the ability to progress either because of bosses being too difficult or some encounters completely overpowering your characters, so creating your party requires very careful planning and even more careful skill point allocation.

Another major problem MMx is balance, or lack off it.  The balance problems are so bad that I don't think the game was ever playtested properly.   Overall game difficulty is another issue as it wildly increases/decreases, for instance you don't know the level of any monsters and since they cut corners with monsters design (they just re-color) the difference in color of a monster could mean that you have your entire party one-shotted or you one-shot the monster.  But for the most part, you'll die ALOT when exploring, so save literally before every encounter.  Because a typical scenerio when exploring is...kill basic monsters...no problems...oh new monster!! Game Over...reload, avoid area until higher level, it happens far too often which makes me wonder if this development team ever played any of the original might and magic games...

I could write on and on about all the complaints and issues I have with this game, but this is one of those games you're either going to love it, or hate it.  I just don't recommend this game to anyone who easily gets frustrated.  It is also especially time consuming because MMx also suffers from excessive loading, with entering buildings/inns...loading...enter/leaving areas...more loading...entering dungeons/new floors...more loading.

Basically, This game needs to have the movement lock removed as that would solve many of the issues.

reviewText:
It looks nice. Although no where as good as the original games ( 1 - 6 were the best in my opinion).

Where this titles falls short is having the gameplay plopped on a grid world. The detail in graphics beg for free roaming, like in MM6. But instead, you're forced on this grid like in MM2/3/4/5. The two styles clash against each other, rather than compliment.

And then there's the combat. It's turn-based meets World of Warcraft inspired hotbar mashing. You wouldn't even know that's how it's played, unless you read a walkthrough. The game never tells you you can click on the ability more than once in a combat turn .

It's just an odd mesh of things that really don't jell together well, unfortunately. I'm sure if you are reall dedicated, you could probably find some enjoyment out of this title. I just couldn't, sadly. Perhaps one day I'll give it another go. Until, I'll play Wizardry 8.

reviewText:
Unfortunately, both non-canon M&M world and poor design (several seconds for a single move/turn? WHAT?), not to mention same attitude towards releasing a product that will reach EoL while still having missing/incomplete features as with Heroes 6 make this game really unattractive.
Even if you are new to M&M, and/or liked Heroes 6 despite plaguing issues, I would not recommend paying more than 20% of the release price (~5 EUR) for the deluxe (or complete, when it releases) edition of this game.
To long-time M&M fans: you will not find any M&M in this game. 'Legacy' is just a marketing ploy, but Ubisoft is known for officially confirming claims even when they know they are wrong at the time of issuing a public 'official' confirmation.
Don't buy it. You don't want to personally become familiar with how Ubisoft treats you and M&M.

reviewText:
This game was a complete letdown. The grid based movement is reminiscent of the previous M&M games of yesteryear, but that is where it pretty much ends.

There is very little content.. what is there is generally boring. There is not a large skillset and the story is rather bland.

The textures and gameworld look like they were from the MM 3-4 era, which was intentional by the developers. However, that seems like a bad decision. The gameplay elements of the older games was great, the graphics not so much.. updating the graphics and providing some rich looking worlds would have went a long way to improve the overall immersion in the game.

There are three towns and only 20 dungeons - that's a very small area to explore and overall, the content is around 20-30 hours of gameplay. That seems weak for any game in the M&M series.

Modding support for the game is almost non-existent unless you are an indie developer with a Unity3D Pro license ($1500 - if you want one..) So, don't expect alot of community mods.

The only good side is that it has a reduced price tag.. But even at $25, its still over priced for what you get. You are better of picking up a dos box and one of the older games in the series - atleast they have less bugs and a solid story.

reviewText:
It looks nice. Although no where as good as the original games ( 1 - 6 were the best in my opinion).

Where this titles falls short is having the gameplay plopped on a grid world. The detail in graphics beg for free roaming, like in MM6. But instead, you're forced on this grid like in MM2/3/4/5. The two styles clash against each other, rather than compliment.

And then there's the combat. It's turn-based meets World of Warcraft inspired hotbar mashing. You wouldn't even know that's how it's played, unless you read a walkthrough. The game never tells you you can click on the ability more than once in a combat turn .

It's just an odd mesh of things that really don't jell together well, unfortunately. I'm sure if you are reall dedicated, you could probably find some enjoyment out of this title. I just couldn't, sadly. Perhaps one day I'll give it another go. Until, I'll play Wizardry 8.

reviewText:
A caveat: it was a close call whether to recommend this game or warn people off it. Keep that in mind when reading the rest of the review.

Might and Magic X is basically a turn-based hack-and-slash game, and it's strength lies in providing a slightly more cerebral version of the Diablo-like experience: kill waves of monsters with sword and spell, loot the corpses (considerately done automatically in this case), level up and get new powers with which to kill monsters, rinse, repeat. There are people who give you quests, but they're not especially memorable in terms of personality or backstory. Your own characters are flat generic PCs. There a main plot involving insurrection and hidden puppetmasters, and as best I can discern it doesn't have any gaping holes, but it doesn't reach the level of the Dragon Age franchise, much less something like Fallout or Bloodlines. It does, however, provide plenty of turn-and-grid-based combats against enemies with somewhat varied abilities, plus plenty of PCs to customize and difficult, meaningful choices about how to allocate skill points (the source of many of my own considerable play hours.)

In general, MM X delivers the turn-based tactical-RPG goods. In particular, however, there are a number of annoyances that detract from the experience:

-OCD is mandatory. you need spells of Clairvoyance, Light, Whispering Shadows, a way to repair damaged gear (difficult when in the middle of the wilderness), antidotes and/or Cure Poison, one character with Might primary, one with Magic, one with Perception, etcetera, etcetera. Neglecting any particular little thing will at the very least cost you some opportunities and at most court a Total Party Kill

-Hard fights aren't smart fights. Especially hard fights don't require that much tactical sophistication- once you've got a schtick your party can reliably resort to, for instance focusing fire on one enemy while Dark Magic users neutralize the other ones with Sleep, you just have to go through the motions. That means doing the same thing turn after turn, occasionally guzzling potions (of which you will need many). Most of the thinking goes into allocating your characters' skill points when leveling them up, before combat begins.

-Take a wrong turn and die. Non-linear game worlds with difficult areas available early can be good things. The problems here are that a) there's relatively little indication of what you're getting yourself into, and b) you can't retreat from a fight (barring, maybe, one or two high-level spells that let you), which means saving and reloading. Think Skyrim, if you didn't have the option of running away from the big ugly like your pants were on fire and instead had to stand next to him trading blows until you drop, or just reload.

The game has somewhat more good points than bad, enough to hope that the studio will correct these faults to produce a more enjoyable Might and Magic XI

reviewText: I tried very hard to like this game. Some of my favorite gaming memories are playing early M&M games. I love the retro feel and tile based movement. I like how combat is thoughful and real strategy is needed. However this game just feels unfinished. There appears to be no real and obvious progression as you move through areas. The difficulty spikes in odd places to unplayable levels then lowers to easy for no apparent reason. The loading times are insane for a game of limited quality. The mini map is very poor and there is no way to back out of combat without reloading. If a game needs a narator for more than the opening sequence more though needs to be put into the story. Lastly the character portraits should change as you upgrade your equipment. I found this game exceedengly fustrating to play and after about 100 hours going to quit for a while.

reviewText:
Might & Magic X - Legacy


Concept:
A Dungeon crawling old school hack-and-slash RPG set in the Heroes of Might and Magic World.

Graphics: ★★★☆☆
Not Skyrim, but for  a 3D grid-base dungeon crawler it looks pleasing.

Sound: ★★★☆☆
The music is reminiscent of some of the classic Might & Magic titles as well as the Heroes of Might and Magic series. Sound effects are simple and repetitive.

Playability: ★★★★☆
Easy controls and interface like its predecessors.

Entertainment: ★★★☆☆
If your familiar with games of the past like the Wizardry series or the Might & Magic games, you will love this title as it takes you down memory lane but for those who are new to these type of games may get bored as the gameplay may get repetitive.

Replay Value: ★★★★☆
I feel the game has a High replay value especially since your party consists of 4 members and there are a total of 12 possible Classes to mix and match with the 4 races.

Overall Rating: ★★★½☆☆



MY PERSONAL REVIEW


The Game takes place a few years after the events of Might & Magic: Heroes VI. Might & Magic X - Legacy takes place on the Agyn Peninsula. It's a throwback to the hack-and-slash RPGs of old and no knowledge of the past series is required to play it. You can create a Four person party consisting of 4 Races and 12 Classes to select from. While the party size is locked at four, players can pick up additional hirelings to fill specialized needs that give certain buffs or the pack horse that adds a considerable amount of inventory space which I found a must. The classes offer lots of skills and spells to choose from. The individual skills can be ranked up starting at novice and going up to Grandmaster. Some of the spells you get at Grandmaster are devastating but the road to get there is a long one. If you liked the Diablo style loot drops than you’ll like this game as there is a ton of different types of loot. The game adds some puzzle and riddle solving to take away from the constant combat grind.  Players can roam towns to find various power ups, coins, and quests that send them out into the wilderness. The game offers about 60+ Hours of play time if you explore every nook and cranny and take the time to read all the Lore it offers. This game is nothing like the Heroes of might & Magic series but if you liked games of the past like the Wizardry or Eye of the Beholder series or even the new Legend of Grimrock than this is the game for you.

reviewText:
http://youtu.be/SJ8erVT5TkE


Might & Magic X Legacy in its current state offers some excellent music, solid adventure and some fine character customization making for a worthy game to invest many hours in. Whilst the tile based gameplay might be a little dated, if you can look past this and enjoy the game for what it is, there's an large dose of adventure to be had here for any Might & Magic enthusiast and anyone else who wants in on something slightly off the beaten track. Might & Magic X Legacy is available via Early Access on Uplay and Steam for £19.99 and includes the full game when released, a ton of extra features including the option for the community to make their own content. If early access isn't your thing, then be sure to keep an eye out for the full game when it releases.

reviewText:
I'm a fan of M&M. I love this series because of VI. I don't know why M&M X come back to I~V. It seems that the production team just lacks money.  M&M X, as the sequel of one of the greatest RPGs in Europe and America, could have been an epic game. Blame UBISOFT. Why can't they invest more money in this series? I remember the time when I was addicted to playing M&M VI for two whole weeks. Afterall, it's just an early edition. I'm still looking forward to some improvement.
=====================================================================
Now the official edition has released. I find this game is just okay after I have played for several hours. There are two points that should be improved. The first one is the inventory. Weapons shouldn't only be icons like M&M IX. It is very disappointing when we defeat boss and get loots whose apperance we can only see from pictures. The second one is about our characters' heads at the bottom. More expressions and actions should be added in order to increase sense of indentification. These two points are also the essence of M&M.
Overall, its not too bad. It would be a great game if it was made for smart phone.
6/10
