reviewText:
This game very effectively captures the 'old school' vibe of the M&M games of the days of yore, but also effectively moves the gameplay into a modern context.  The Xeen series is clearly the main inspiration for this title and the various RPG systems in the game interact effectively to create a compelling and addictive experience.

Exploring the world and discovering new locales is really enjoyable although the graphics are relatively cut-rate compared to similar titles.  Some locations look more impressive than others.  The dungeons in particular are quite well-designed, but the overworld and towns lack visual cohesion and suffer from occasional performance hiccups.

The combat is the meat of the game and  is purely tactical.  Enemies have a variety of abilities to keep you on your toes.  Don't settle into any one tactic or rely on key-spamming, you constantly have to adapt your abilities to the foes at hand.

The lore and world building gets the job done, although exposition is occasionally heavy-handed and long-winded.

The grid movement system may feel constrained at first, but if you think of the game more like a series of large chess-like game boards, it makes more sense.  Simplifying the spacialization of enemies and move options to a grid forces you to make specific choices over what you can do spatially in combat - a good thing for a game of relatively modest scope.

The main point I want to get about this game is that, as much as the game wants you to, you don't have to look at it through a nostalgia lens.  The RPG systems and tactical combat that hold this game together transcend both the weight of history that hangs over the series and expectations from fans of the genre.

Come in with the right amount of expectations and you'll find that the developers acheived what they set out to do: bring the essense of what made the old Might games such a joy to play and put it in a modern context.  Given the modest resources they had at their disposal and the weight of history they had to stare down, I believe Limbic Entertainment succeeded admirably.

reviewText:
Yeah, I’ve played this game for 100+ hours, finished it 5 times, get almost all achievements… Yet I disregard it. Why?

Well, all blame goes to Ubisoft, and two major points for I don’t recommend that game are:
-	a wrong key feature policy (bad plan), and
-	Insultingly high price, considering how low-tech, and limited in capacity that volume is.

What is wrong key feature policy, you may ask? Well, that game proposes itself as HardCore and Oldschool. That’s the point for that I want to crush skulls and jaws. You see, using the old mechanic is not making the game oldschool. Forfeiting base common tricks, like adjustable map or in-game notepad, does not making it hardcore.

The main reason for what people love old games is not about any type of mechanics. It is about passion! Guys who made those old games on their knees, in the dusty garages, but with full care a parent can give to its child – where every piece in every place is literally hand-made – that’s for people getting old-school. When Finnish Almost Human studio hit the shelves in the 2012 with the Legend of Grimrock, their game was praised not for using sluggish square-based movement. No, please! It was all about good combination of long-known tricks with the creativity and that famous “from gamers to gamers” drive.

Might and Magic X Legacy in fact is just a tribute to old 3DO hits, snatchingly made by a small amateur game studio Limbic for a paycheck, and then sold as a full-scale hit by Ubisoft.

Now, I don’t think that subsidiarity is a bad idea. It is one of the basic principles of the European Union, for example. But sometimes subsidiarity is not a good option. So rich is the fan-base of the old Might & Magic series! It is certainly have no less admirers than Deus Ex. Were Might and Magic X Legacy a stand-alone project, with some different name (Legend of Eryn, why not?) – I’d only recommend it. But as an inheritor of the whole serial… it is not even a basttard, it is an impostor.  When I’m hearing its name, it sounds to me like, “Leo Romanoff, the right heir to the Russian throne”.

That’s all about two major aspects, for which I’m turning it down. Now, the base routine: normal review for a game without such big name.

What we have is a first-person view RPG with tile-based movement (like in the M&M 1-5 or the Legend of Grimrock). There go some fans of M&M 6-8… I know some of them, and they don’t happy about that turn. What I didn’t like about that style of movement is that I constantly losing the track. Especially if the background is not flat, like in the Crag town. When you climbing up there, it is cool. But when you have to descend… you can’t look down! So you move, but don’t see where, because you don’t see ground! Un-natural, that concept is.

The battle system is turn-based, of course: you have four of your characters, you make a move for every of them, then comes enemies, and so on, one for one. While challenge in those turn-based combats is quite high sometimes, the bad thing is that it is very clumsy in any case where you not strong enough just to click enemy to death with single attack. It goes about applying your characters skills via game interface. Yeah, you have 10 buttons, 5 already binded (1-melee, 2-shot, 3-block, and 2 buttons for red and blue potions). Another 5 buttons are yours to bind, but boy, that’s so far from enough!

After you get about 10-15 level, you’ll be constantly using sub-subdirectories to make every move for every character. I always thought that western PC RPG stands above JRPG like Final Fantasy, when we speaking about normalcy, convenience of combat performing. Alas, the turn-based fight in the M&M X is worse than in your normal JRPG. In the most of the battles it feels like romp in the mud.

The story? Nothing spectacular. Go from A to B, then to C, return to A, to B, another round with new mail quest, and another. Wait! Twist! (bonfires) And go for another 3 rounds between A, B and C!

There are too little place for decent amount of adventuring. Some locations are blowing my mind, but in the bad way. You go through a tomb full of ghouls and ghosts, managing through some part of it, and then – whoa! – you’re meet humans. Not necromancers. You think, well, I finished the tomb part; there is a Rubicon, now it is a human dungeon. You reconfiguring your skills to fit the fencing with humans, then hop! Another ghost attack! No logical explanation, what people and undead doing jointly, but they’re performing some cohabitation. Why? Well, not because it is a great plan of some kind. There are simply not enough place for two dungeons and variety of enemies for every maze you’ll have to see on your way through.

Game falls low shortly after start. It is unnatural, bleak, and the only good point in it is the retro battle system, which gives you some trial to see if you’re fit to old standards. Oh, wait, I’ve already said that that system is clumsy and broken there! So – generally – there are no point to start it, at all!

If only to cherish your curiosity… Save your time, don’t bother. My mark is 6/10.

PS: I've almost forgot, but this is important piece: the sound in the game is its worst part. After about two hours of playing I was urged to shut down the voices, then, after I've got to Seahaven, I switched off the ambient, and it was not long until I totally mute the game and played only with my own soundtrack on background. What's so bad? Buzzing sounds. That's a total disaster, believe me. Limbic should shot their sound engineer, or at least, stop feeding him.

reviewText: This is a pretty poor imitation of the original (or at least later) Might & Magic RPG's.  Despite the appearance of an open world the game is strictly linear and poorly designed.  The encounters are of the type where the NPC's frequently get to break the rules in one way or another and the game is not using cheap tricks like having enemies magically appear in areas you just cleared when you enter combat.  If this sort of game interests you I strongly recommend against purchasing this title and suggest you look elsewhere for your entertainment.

reviewText:
Were you OK with Wizardry 8? That was one half-finished game, even more so than M&MX. That didn't stop it from being very good, though.

Play M&MX if:

1) You want an open-world, turn-based and grid-based dungeon crawler.

2) You are fine with thinking about class and party builds ahead of playing the game. M&MX on warrior difficulty is hard, some would say even brutal - even a very strong, metagamey party will get consistently challenged. You can't max out every skill (at most you'll max 3 skills out of 10+ available for each class) so you have to pick and choose carefully as well as making sure that your classes work well together.

3) You can appreciate the fact that it's actually very open. Recently we've been fed fake open-world games like Divinity OS and Xulima where you're actually meant to do things in a very specific order. M&MX handles this aspect very well so that going into a hard area, barely managing it through encounters and coming back some epic loot feels nice and rewarding.

Don't play it if:

1) You want a casual game.

2) You want a faithful clone of Xeen or another M&M6. This is different - though it does borrow a lot of things from the older M&M's, at least style-wise.

2) You hate turn-based, grid-based gameplay.

3) Can't handle bugs, glitches and lack of polish.

Have fun!

reviewText:
I missed the information that this is a TURN-BASED game (and not real-time).  I loved games as Dungeon Master and Eye of the beholder. But I am sorry to say that this game is not like these old real-time games at all. If you enjoyed those old game this game is most likely not for you. Those are the main reasons:

1. All battles are lock-and-fight-turn-based
2. Every step you take is counted as a turn (meaning that all creatures stand still until you make your next move). In short: this is a boardgame in 3D environment.

Best wishes

reviewText:
I'm not entirely sure this is a fitting homage to the series, let alone a worthy sequel to the original Might and Magic first person adventure games. This feels more like a Wizardry game than anything, only it does not have random encounters.

If you're looking for an updated version of M&M 6: The Mandate of Heaven, you're going to notice immediately that combat is turn based instead of action based and that you're not able to cheese the ranged attacks quite the same way you did in the last few titles. This forces the element of difficulty into the game that used to come from having to strategize about when and where to cast spells and run from enemies. Once engaged in melee combat, you can't back away or use exits, and very often you're arbitrarily ambushed and beaten down from behind. This leaves little to no strategy available to the player to decide when and where to engage the enemy. Worse still, every skill you need to progress is gated by leveling up multiple times and collecting money, which there is a limited amount of in the game.

This entire game feels like it was designed by people who did not play the original series and do not fully understand the mystique and challenge of M&M adventure games. The elements are there but different. Most of the difficulty in this game comes from needing to block or chug potions at the right time. And you can't even equip the best shields available to you in the first town. You have to complete several incredibly difficult dungeons and make it to the second town before you're even allowed to purchase the training to equip them. This makes the fights with tougher enemies frustrating if not outright unfair. Those who would focus on defense to secure the best outcome are punished while people who choose whatever deals the most damage are rewarded; All in all, this is par for the course for turn based games but not balanced the way M&M 1-6 were. Moreover, entire methods of playing the game, such as going with heavy armor and shields, goes completely unrewarded, so there's no point to that portion of the content. You do not have a front-line and a back-line since enemies can reach any of your party members to attack them at any time, so there isn't even signficant incentive to have defensive members balancing against softer damage dealers until halfway into the game when you actually get usable healing spells. By then, you'd have been better off going full barbarian or mage across the board.

The only genuinely positive part of this experience is that the dungeons and quests all string together nicely like an mmo and it's easy to figure out where to go next just from exploring and poking around on the mini map, talking to people, etc. That and, somehow acknolwedging the limitations of non-respawning chests and enemies, the game apparently dumps loot on you when you find it, so that's nice.

I haven't played a full team of mages like I mentioned earlier yet but I suspect they work much better than the classes I was trying before; And if that is the case, then this is the only great similarity between the original games and this one. Overall, I don't want to take the time to play it anymore after having gotten my butt kicked repeatedly. I'm already too frustrated after a few hours of trudging around in the Lighthouse. The difficulty curve is ridiculous and fights go from being winnable to being totally hopeless, from room to room even. Moreover, there's almost nothing to indicate to you when going in a room or across a bridge will be life threatening so you can never learn from your mistakes. There are even several places you're clearly meant to return to when you're stronger, but how much stronger is somewhere between vaguely incomprehensible and utterly unfathomable. It feels like a big slap in the face when you as a player go in a door that was open to you and can't even escape certain demise because you weren't genuinely going to be allowed an opportunity to succeed at what lay behind it. This kind of high stakes trial-and-error is very unrewarding and disappointing.

Update: I have now played with a full team of mages and it's as I suspected. I was able to get this team to the place of progress it had taken hours to get to before within about 30 minutes. Of course once you run into the one thing that's immune to the school of magic you've been focusing on or up the difficulty from normal to hard, you can expect to be back in the boat of unplayable content and frustration. Overall, the game seems to want to force you to have to bring a specific party to accomplish the goals it sets before you. Some doors can't even be found and some passage ways can't even be opened unless a person with a high score in a specific stat is able to locate and/or open them for your team, which means teams lacking that stat may not even be able to progress in certain dungeons at all. This is very detrimental as, 1) it's impossible to know what the recommended (or required) team composition is upfront and 2) playing with any other party composition is apparently almost futile.

TLDR; This is a competent and somewhat fun to play turn-based RPG but has little to nothing to offer those who are fans of M&M6. I'd still like to recommend this one because it's challenging and a classic first person dungeon crawler like Wizardry, but I can't while it's at any price over 10 dollars. The fact that Wizardry 6 is the same kind of game and was slightly better than this despite having come out 24 years ago prevents me from doing so. If you were hoping to have some fun with this one, buy Wizardry Renaissance and play it all the way through first. Then maybe pick this one up and play it out of boredom when it falls below 10 dollars standard price.

It's a great rendition of the classic turn based fantasy role playing game, but it's way too buggy.  I'd stay away, at least on the Mac version, until they get it fixed.

reviewText:
Requires Uplay, so instead of just Steam running in the background you'll now have ANOTHER DAMN THING running in the background. DO NOT BUY unless you like signing up for stupid bullcrap where they want your email address so they can spam you and sell your information or send you advertising.

Fun if you like to figure out where to go and what to do by trial and death. Save a lot. Reload a lot. There are no respawns, so do your internet research to figure out what your party needs before you go forth, or else you'll be behind the power curve that the game throws at you.

Speaking of internet research, you need to know what quests/areas/subareas to do in what order, or else ...total party kill. There's no way to disengage from combat. You'll die. A lot. Because you didn't do your internet research ahead of time. If this is fun for you, go for it.

Ranged weapons are mostly useless due to the grid system. You'll need to return to town a lot to restock on supplies. Buy tons of mana potions, because there's no mana regen that I can see.

Want to improve your characters? Find the trainers. Run back and forth to town. A LOT. Figure out where the trainers are. YAY SO MUCH FUN. No. It's also grid based, and the texture quality in some notable places is just horri-bad. CHECK OUT THE TOWN NAME ON THE SIGN AS YOU LEAVE THE FIRST TOWN.

lol.

reviewText: Man, really loving the gameplay, the combat is fun, and it feels pretty balanced so far. reviewText: 7.5/10. As a MM fan having played all MM games, this game actually succeeds in capturing the MM charme and spirit! It is nice to level up, train with trainers, and get to Expert, Master and GM status. The game is well balanced, quite difficult at the beginning, so that you will need to come back later for some bosses, and even in late game, remains challenging. reviewText: M&M X: Legacy - for those of us who have been playing games BEFORE Steam, and before the internet was the monster it has become, there were games played on boards, and before that, paper. Once computers entered the gaming world a few people wrote games in text only format to entertain the infant market. I even wrote a Star Trek game on the Commodore 64 that was stored on a floppy disk! M&M X is a new game which captures a little of the older, but not as old as that old C64 game I wrote. And thank heaven for that! Greatly improved graphics over past iterations of the M&M world, smoother play, old style movement and enough creatures, bad guys, and other diversions to keep the most stout-hearted adventurer in the game for many hours. This game uses an older type of interface that the younger generation might find clunky" but this is only because they have no basis for comparison. Humor is always required in an adventure game as are challenges which increase in difficulty level as progress is made make gaming as time consuming blast! The first dragon encountered is very much a challenge worthy of the best warrior party - for this dragon is beautiful but deadly. Cyclops are always a challenge and M&M X gets it right by inserting a cave with a cyclops standing inside the entrance and it carries a club. Your party is in grave danger and there is no leaving the cave until the danger is past...er...dead. Get a horse early and let it carry the extra armor and weapons you collect along the way
date: leaving your arms free to hold a sword and shiled. Keep gold in your pockets though
recommended: horses can't be trusted!\nEasy to play
hoursPlayed: addictive style that will captivate the most jaded players due to the strangely adaptive A.I.

votesTotal: a definite blast-from-the-past title that will keep you journeying and adventuring for hours on end."

reviewText:
I grew up on M&M games, sometimes spending all night playing them when I was younger.  When I found this game I was excited enough to just buy it without checking the reviews.  That was unfortunate, especially as a Mac user first, and Windows user second.
This game does not work on Mac.  It is simple as that.  There are just too many stability problems.  It is consistently locking up at various times.
As a M&M fan, the game play is nostalgiac.  It may not be exciting enough for new comers to the series, however.  I do enjoy playing it because of the connection I had to all the previous games years ago.

Recommendation is No because it really is not compatible with Mac computers.

Edit: OK.  I am going to change my review based on Windows version.  It works fine and is still pretty fun to play.  It reminds me of the days when I played many years ago and I have no problems with the game so far.  This is after completing Story 1 on the Windows Version.

Mac version is still garbage.

reviewText:
Highly recommend Might and Magic X - Legacy

The game is a perfect throwback to games I loved in the 80s and 90s.  It requires lots of thought to balance survivability and damage.  Putting a lot of thought into character development helps create an engrossing game experience.

It's turn based, so it may appeal more to laidback gamers.  Success depends on planning, rather than mashing the keys at the right time.

There is a great variety of spells and fighting styles, so for me there is replayability to try different spell schools and weapon types.

I hope the developers make expansions based on this game, and look forward to the next edition.

reviewText:
The game is ok-ish at best. I am a huge Might & Magic fan and I always go back to mm6, mm7 and mm8.
The game kinda stays in the same category and it can be a pleasant experience.

There are a few things which put me off :

1. Grid based movement. I mean 3DO build a world where you could move freely and so many years later Ubisoft can't do the same ? Really bad.

2. The game is very small and the story lacking compared to any previous game.

3. No flying !

4. The biggest turn off for me was the complete lack of gear display. In any M&M game you could see the appearance of your character changing with every piece of gear equipped. You could what an armour looks like, on your character. This is actually very important for an RPG game. M&M X - no, sorry, w can't allow you to see that.

5. skill advancement is blocked so you can't invest points as you could before. Once you hit the max level in a skill that's it, rogression stopped.

All these things aside, the game is fun and worth playing. It can be challenging especially on warrior difficulty. If you liked the previous M&M games you will learn to love this one as well.

reviewText:
I loved it and had a great time playing it, but you may not.  So, let's discuss it's progency, for a moment.

The game owes it's existence to the joyful Legend of Grimrock, which did a great job updating the games of my youth.  MMX is an even more direct throwback to the original Bard's Tale in 1985.  The Bard's Tale took Wizardry and added outdoor areas.  Sure, they weren't that different -- they were basically dungeons with sky blue tiles as opposed to underground grey and brown tiles, but the effect worked on me.

If you have some nostalgia for the early days of RPG gaming, this will likely hit a home run.  It reminds me of playing games on my Apple II, even including watching the graphics render.  What I really enjoyed most was developing my characters and watching them become increasingly powerful.  I wanted them well prepared for the final battle, and there are many opportunities to improve their skills and their loot.

Pros:
- RPG nostalgia
- Good skills and character development options
- Good magic system
- The individual quests and dungeon were mostly fun
- Combat is well done
- To me, at least, the game is almost perfectly balanced (with the stock party).  Only toward the end did I begin to feel overpowered.  Most of the game, the battles were close and tense, but rarely did my entire party die.
- Great opportunities for exploration -- there is always something new to find
- No monster respawns!!  Once you clear an area, it stays clear.  I like that.

Cons:
- Graphics look good, but take a long time to render.  At one point, the landscape renders well before the castle sitting on the landscape renders.  That's just weird.
- Members have your party have comments about everything going on around them.  I love that.  Except that they repeat the same things over and over and over again.  We get it... human cities are as dangerous as the jungle.  Let's move on.  When characters finish a major battle, they cheer an entirely disingenuous Yay!"  It sounds exactly like a bunch of poorly paid actors sitting around their home microphones trying to appear enthusiastic.

reviewText:
First off, the bad stuff. This game has a few frustrating elements put there by the developers. Poison will kill you, and quite quickly, and you get no warning that you need to get earth magic's cure poison or buy antidotes before you get poisoned the first time, although hopefully you will have picked up enough antifotes to be okay. Secondly, while both the team and monsters are locked in space when they enter a melee fight (which is fine), there is one boss that doesn't, and who is going to push the team to their death if the I guess random number generator wills it. Lastly, a couple of things are very difficult to find, and there's no abundance of hints to where to go and the voice acting isn't that great.

Apart from that, Might and magic X is a truly brilliant game. You start off choosing a team of four characters whose skills will complement each other on their Quest through the Agyn peninsula. From there on, everything is grid and turn based. You will move square by square through an astonishing world with a lot, really a lot, of cool secrets you may have to go out of your way to find. The game is really well made for people who like to explore places, as the world is big, and the only thing keeping you from going places are monsters. You will need to save often, as you may be ambushed by too difficult monsters in the early game, but even really difficult monsters can often be overcome if you employ the right strategy. Mages are given powerful but costly control options, and there are lots of different strategies to employ to get past the bad guys. Being turn based, you can even change your equipment during your turn in combat, yielding very interesting options if you stack up on cool equipment. This results in a lot of digressions from the tasks at hand; the party will find a new nook or cave they want to explore while on their way to the next location. Except for interdependent quests, you can mosttimes do any quest you have in any order you'd like.

While difficult monsters can often be overcome with the right tactics (or a couple of levels, there are always other things you want to do in the mean time), easy monsters can often kill the party if you don't pay attention. The simplest monsters give 5 xp, the toughest give you around 50, so you will never feel that you are too strong for an area, you simply spend less turns during each combat.

One of the aspects that really got me in this game was all the puzzles. All the way through the land they have put mysterious crypts, where you need to solve a puzzle to get to the treasure, with no dangerous monsters to distract you. There are a lot of chests which requires you to answer a riddle correctly, and they are very fun to ponder about, especially if you're playing together with someone. I already said there are a lot of treasure in this game, and it is sometimes hidden due to the movement in the game. If there's a chest to your side, you won't notice it unless you face that direction, and as you can't face every wall all the time, you need to keep looking for small boxes or camuflaged chests you need to face.

For the level system, I think it's good. every level gives you 4 attribute points, to be spread over strength, perception, destiny, magic, etc. with very clear effects. This makes sure your character gets better at what he/she does at every level. The character also gets 3 skill points, which can be spent on increasing skills. All the skills a character chan choose between, he/she can master to different degrees, expert (at 7 skill points), master (at 15) and grand master (at 25). At these scores, advancement needs to be bought from a skill specific trainer, which will give an extra boost and let the character advance further. There are 12 classes to choose between, and each has a different set of skill mastery possibilities, but each class needs to get promoted through a special quest to access gm training (range -> warden can gm bow, barbarian -> warmonger can gm two handed), so the game really makes you work to become better. I already mentioned that mages have interesting battle control options; the fighters also do. There's a skill called warfare, which grants spell like abilities (two more at each new level of mastery) like reducing armor or taunting enemies to attack that particular character. This makes any kind of team viable, and gives the game a lot of replay value. When I say any kind of team is viable, I mean it, character creation is not something you need to ponder a lot on, there will be ways to destroy every enemy with what you want to play. Also, at gm level, you will be insanely good, and your party will feel like living gods. This feels great.

I had a lot of fun all the way through this game. They have managed to scare me through sending enemies on me that I didn't think I could handle, they have given me riddles and puzzles I didn't feel like I could handle, but I did, and it was great. If anything is too hard or obscure, you can always google it, you will still enjoy the world of asha. Turn based and grid based games aren't for everyone, and it's difficult to do it well. I hated legend of grimlock, as the movement was annoying, and you could kick difficult bosses asses by figuring out their movement patterns. What they did badly, MMX has done in a very smooth way. Id you liked the stroy part of Heroes VI, then you'll love this game, as they expand upon it with great pieces of lore scattered around (and a story that follows in the footstep of Heroes VI). If you played the old games, you will definitely love this one, as they have included lord Kilburn and Crag Hack, as well as lore about Lord Caneghem"."

There's not a lot of hand-holding -- with riddles, puzzles, and high-level mobs strewn about the continent. reviewText:
As a hardcore M&M series gamer and have finished this game. What this game lacks can be described in one word and that word is grandness. Start with music department. It is relatively weak and as I am writing this, I can't remember any of its melody. Whereas if I am asked to play music from M&M 6 on a piano now. I can do it in a heartbeat and it was more than 16 years ago since I first played M&M 6. Next thing is items. In Legacy, items are represented by small icons inside inventory window. How lame is that. A two-handed axe has the same dimension and takes up the same amount of spaces as an one-handed dagger. It just feels cheap and low quality. Another thing M&M 6 outshines Legacy is  critters. Where are titans, medusas and dragons? You even get to kill angels in previous games. In Legacy, minotaurs are pretty much the only epic monster left. And it is introduced early in the game (Act 2). By the time you reache the end, most of the monsters you are fighting are human like. If I want to kill human, I might as well be playing Battlefield 4.
However, this game has shown some improvements. Improvements like spells. In Legacy, they have removed many useless spells. But dark school magic is still a waste of time once you reach expert level. Battles are not as grand but require more tactic. Map and towns are not huge, if you like sightseeing you may get disapointed. But the good part is that you don't waste too much time travelling around.
Overall, this is a good game. If you are looking for an old school RPG. This is it. If you are a M&M fan looking for something that would blow every M&M game out of water. You may get disappointed. But Legacy is certainly worth a try.

reviewText: When I finally decided to buy this game, I was a little bit wary having read a lot of mixed critics and user reviews. I believe Might & Magic X is a great game (considering also its low budget), and a worthy successor to the older ones of the series. The gameplay still remains very addictive, true to its roots and personally, I find the graphics pretty good considering that high - end visual results is not something you are looking for in a game like this. If you are a fan of the Might & Magic universe (or the good old turn-based RPGs) you really have to try this one. If not... this is your chance people! This game is really worth it! ;)\n\nP.S. I really enjoyed Legend of Grimrock, but I think its not fair to compare it to Might and Magic X having in mind that the combat system in LoG is actually real-time. I believe LoG and M&M X are two very different games, both really great and worth playing!

reviewText: If you like turn-based grid-style RPG games, this is a great one to pick up on the cheap.  Yes, you do hit a wall around Act 2, but if you power through it, you will be rewarded with fun.  This game is very buggy, and I was fortunate to have game-breaking bugs at the very end, but I was able to get through them.  The game itself is right up my alley in the kind of RPGs I miss from my younger years.  I was able to beat this with a Blademaster, Rune Priest, Druid, and Freemage, and I have watched quite a few win with other combinations, leading me to beieve that you can beat the game with any makeup, provided you spec into their strengths and figure a combat strategy that will keep you alive.

reviewText:
+ Nice combination of old school turn-based RPG and modern comfort features (annotatable automap, easy comparison between different items via mouse-over, rest anywhere instead of only in safe zones etc).

+ Turn-based battles require a lot of micro-management of your character's spells and skills. For me, it was a great part of the fun of MMX - for other players this might be a turn-off.

+ Thoughtful management of your character's attributes and new skill points is a must - but it's also very rewarding when you reach a new weapon proficiency or finally master a new, powerful spell.

+ Decent variety of enemies, though there are only about two to three different types per dungeon / overworld area. Each type of enemy has different resistances and skills - you have to adapt your attacks / buffs / debuffs accordingly.

+/- Loads and loads of loot, but too often enemies drop only useless stuff (weak weapons and armour for the most part). On the other hand, a decent number of powerful relics" (weapons
date: armour) can be found in the most remote and dangerous areas of the game. These relics make a real difference in battle
recommended: especially as you can level them up (4 levels each) by simply having them equipped in battle. Levelled up to max
hoursPlayed: these relics are the most powerful items in the game.\n\n+/- You will often run into enemies who are simply too strong for your characters

reviewText: This was the best news! I have been a huge fan of the M&M games going back to M&M3 what, almost 20 years ago? The later games were ok but after 6 they seemed to lose that M&M feel. So enter M&MX all the way in 2014. It is awesome! The game play is the same, it hasn't suffered at all. I really feel like I'm back in high school staying up way too late just to finish filling in the map. So much fun. If you aren't a fan of the older games this will probably look dated and the grid like maps may feel like you are locked in, but honestly I love these things. This game fits like an old glove and I have no criticisms. Plus if you buy the delixe version you get M&M6 which is a great deal as well. Challenging puzzles, lots of loot, a methodical pace. What else can I say? <3

reviewText: Yo, if you like old school RPGs in the veins of say the Might and Magic series or Lands of Lore you need to get this. It runs on a grid so it's less fluid than Escape from Grimrock (another game that harkens back to the time of old school RPGS), but that gives it an even greater retro charm, hell it even has an option for fuzzy retro graphics. It pays greatest homage to Might and Magic 1-4, it still does give refrences to six and seven (seven being my absolute favorite of the series). It even gives the synopsis of the plots for each previous game in in-game lore books while maintaining the new lore and world.\n\nThough character creation is limited to four races with three classes for each race, it's still not as bad as Might Magic XIII's character creation (IDK about you guys but that game had the worst race/class choices in the series). Combat can be a bit buggy at times, the latest patch seems to have fixed a lot of the release issues, so I can now give this game my full approval.

reviewText: What can you say!!! I loved Might & Magic v1 The Mandate of Heaven it was a real challenge to play, the battles were tough and  you always had great feeling when you fought the battle's and won .... Might & Magic X-Legacy is extreamly frustrating to get used with the controls at the begining but something clicks as you peservere and you get used to the controls and it becomes a really good challenging game, I love the modern graphics which really improve the experience of the game it brings Might & Magic to life ..... Such an improvement I'm really loving playing this game, Its downside is the slightly long loading screens but you can get used to this, and where is the don't touch the mercendise! gone, or when you leave the chapel Bless you!  Me I miss that from Might & Magic v1, but other than that its really only the awkward get used to the controls bit!.... I recomend this to anyone who played the early M&M games,  this has a great retro feel and  the modern graphics are absolutely brilliant...... As said  a lot would be put off by the awkward controls at the start but if you stick with it! its an extreamly  good & challenging game to play!.......

reviewText:
short summary / Kurzzusammenfassung: game concept is quite nice, but too many bugs + flaws. / Spielkonzept ist ganz nett (habe auch einige andere M&M-Teile gespielt, es gibt aber zu viele Bugs und sonstige Mängel


long version
after playing several other rpg-style games from the M&M, the dark eye, D&D, gothic and alike series i was looking forward to play another nice game. After a quite nice start ( just a bit annoying expert/master/grandmaster-skillsystem ) the waiting on loads more and more angered me (takes 20s-1min per load).

later on you will find out that it really sucks to come to an area which might be relevant for quests without picking those quests before. On some game-important occasions like promotion missions you will end up with an open quest unable to complete it, if you've been to the quest-relevant area before. other bugs will add up, you will have problems to become grandmaster on some skills before it stops to matter if you are, and so on and on. Some things can be fixed when using boards to understand the game scripts, but honestly: this shouldnt be a player's deal at all.

Especially annoying are the relics. Of about 30 relics in the game about 2-5 might be of good use for your team, the rest is weaker than equipment that you can buy (granted you have the time to rest and reload often enough to reset shops), or you simply cannot use it with the party you chose.

on late stages (about level 25-30), depending on your chosen skills and equipment, you either wont have any mentionable enemies (i killed the last boss of the main quest with 3 hits once), or you'll have quite some problems to win it. For example: there is equipment adding +6 of a certain skill. depending on the skill you can achieve 25 (grandmaster) + 48 (2x6 foki, 3x6 jewelry, and 3x6 other equipment) for magic skills, which is damn much OP. you also could try to become invulnurable, wich is no hard task with some of the characters (about 100 defense, about 100 resistences).

but besides all that, at the end of the game you'll have to flee from a prison, having no equipment at start, being able to do lots of mistakes while fleeing. combined with the waiting time for reload, that was too much of frustration for me.

even though i played that game quite some time, i cannot recommend it.

reviewText: If you are old enough to play the old Might and Magic series, and kept going back for more, then Legacy is probably for you. This really is just like playing M&M again, but dressed up for the current PC. Yes, it can be hard, and yes enemies can come at you from all sides, but don't let the haters fool you, this is very fine and worthy successor to those old M&M games. And you certainly get your moneys worth -- the game has many hours of gameplay in it. I am still in Act III and have logged up 30 hours plus.\n\nThoroughly recommended, especially for the more mature gamer out there who remembers what CRPGs were like in the 1980s.

reviewText:
Solid, but not exceptional.

I'm a huge fan of Might and Magic IV and V, which Legacy is heavily inspired by. Indeed, in many ways this is almost MMIV/V with 3D graphics, and more text.

That said, while MMX is definitely fun, it lacks the sense of humour and scale of its predecessors. MMIV/V had you exploring an entire planet, while Legacy keeps you on a single archapeligo. Despite the fact that there's still lots to explore, this does make everything feel oddly cramped. While the cities in X are about as far apart as those in IV and V, they feel much closer (and there's fewer of 'em). It's a minor issue, really, but it kinda sums up the game: The same as what came before, but somehow cramped.

As for the style: The old Might and Magic games didn't take themselves at all seriously. Well over 3/4 of the people you talk to were jokes. X is much more serious. It certainly has jokes, but there are fewer of them, replaced with lots of text. Usually I love lots of text in games, but here there are so many characters and factions to keep track of (and it definitely helps to have played Heroes VI by the same devs and set in the same world) that it becomes hard to really care about them, which is a shame, because the actual plot has loads of potential.

All-in-all, it's a buy if you like games such as Legend of Grimrock (though that's real time to MMX's turn based), Etrian Odyssey, or the old Might and Magic titles, then it's well worth a buy. If the idea of slowly working your way through a dungeon where one bad decision or unlucky chance can doom you, then this ain't for you.

reviewText:
Very enjoyable RPG,

High quality 2D art, unfortunately can't say the same for the 3D art. Music is alright and special effect sound are not annoying.
The games has an enjoyable way to develop your 4 characters. Due to a wide range available spells, magic characters are somewhat more interesting than melee characters.

Unfortunately the game is somewhat buggy, but inside a forgivable range. Loading times are very slow, which requires developer's attention. Journal/Quest system is not very clear, sometimes it’s very hard to find your way around the quest.

I defiantly recommend this game for players which enjoy old-school RPG games and love to build a character with items and skills. I give this game 8/10 points, due to long loading times and some minor bugs which can be easily addressed in the near future.

-Vlad
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Yikes. Be sure you know what you are buying even if it is only $25.
This is not just retro, it’s a trip back to the computer seventies. Movement is a square at a time. You are limited to the checkerboard regardless of what the picture looks like. Want your team to run off in a diagonal direction? Then get ready for a steady stream of left turn, forward, right turn, forward, left turn, forward, right turn, forward, etc.
The enviroment is simply a desktop background. You can interact with very little that you see. There are no in-game physics. I don’t find this an immersive game play experience.
There is some voice but mostly you will be reading lines. Team comments are limited, my team said “I think they smelled us, who hasn’t taken a bath?” at least 8 times in the 5 hours I've played. I’m not sure how much more of that I can take.
Once an enemy is in sight you are most likely to become “engaged in combat.”   When you are in combat you cannot move, except to spin in place; and you cannot run away, a tactic that would be handy to use when you bump into an enemy too far advanced to handle early in the game.
Not a deal breaker but another irritating thing about the new release is that you can't position your characters where you want in a formation. You can move them in the lineup but there is no overhead view or choice of formation. As far as I can tell, they are standing in a line.
I loved the M&M series and looked forward to playing this with friends but I soon realized this is not the way I remember M&M.  With games like Skyrim, FarCry 3, Dead Island Riptide, M&MX is just too ancient to enjoy. I would have much preferred to see an M & M updated to accommodate free movement, an interactive environment and game physics like Skyrim et al. Such a game would have been interesting and I would have stood in line to plunk down $60 to play it.

reviewText: This game has some potential, but the irritating design choices overwhelm that potential in my mind.\n\nFirst off, open world" this game is not.  You have exactly one direction you can go through the first town
date: you can't even leave town without finishing a railroad quest
recommended: unless I missed something.  And even after leaving your world is made up of "you can go to X different dungeons
hoursPlayed: but X-1 of them will kill you instantly" so you really just have the illusion of choice.  Maybe it opens up past the first region
voteText: but if you have to get that far in to a game for it to be open world
helpfulPercent: it isn't.\n\nThis railroading leads to the biggest issue I have compared to the old games
votesHelpful: party composition.  I'm sure some dedicated players will be able to prove me wrong but I honestly don't feel like most party combinations will be viable in this game because of the mission you have to do before leaving town.  In the old games you could run a full ranged party and soften things up enough before they get to you if you were willing to accept that sometimes you don't soften them up enough and you get stomped.  This game doesn't seem to make that an option since there is no way to skip the first dungeon and it railroads you in to melees without the chance for an opening volley.  And that's not even considering the spells you have to run if you want to be able to explore everything.  Don't have a good coverage of the spell schools?  Prepare to miss a lot or use a guide.\n\nEven with these issues aside the mechanics just don't feel like they're there.  Outside of your weapons skills skill increases just don't seem to do much. reviewText: If you enjoyed the old Might & Magic games, this is OK for a couple of hours, but once the nostalgia wears off, there's not much reason to keep playing.  The format is very dated compared to modern role-playing games, and other than updated graphics, this is backwards step compared to the older games - it's much smaller and simpler, and missing many of the features that made the series interesting (e.g. potion mixing, arcomage card game).  Movement is constrained to a fixed grid and real-time play has been completely removed.  Combat locks you in place, and you can get a wide range of difficulty of monsters in a small area, so it's easy to find yourself up against something you can't beat with no means of running away.\n\nI bought the version that comes with a copy of M&M VI, and it says a lot that I've spent far more time playing that!

reviewText:
Not bad. It can't hold a candle to might and magic 6 - 8, but its better than it could have been. Now on to the details...

Likes: I like unique classes for each race.  In older might and magic games I often found my self falling into a pattern of bringin THE caster class, THE fighter, and so on. M&M 10 allows me to try different types of each character arctype and find a party style that works for me.  I like the characters and environment. The party characters FEEL like M&M party members have always felt, right down to the sarcastic comments and cheesy one-liners.  I love the sound sampling from older M&M games (the coin pickup and quest complete sounds come to mind).  The environments are fairly typical fantasy fare, but I enjoy fantasy games, so no problems there.

Dislikes: Slimmed down skill/class system.  There is no dissarm trap skill. No alchemy. None of the old support skills from older M&M games.  I feel that those kind of non-combat (or at least non-weapon/spell) skills were an important part of building a party of living characters.  You didn't just take a party of all Knights and Sorcerers because you needed someone to open the chests and sell the loot.  By taking away those support skills you limit the kind of play experience a player can have.   M&M 10 therefore leans more on its combat with minor exporation elements.

Final Verdict: 7 out of 10.  Good try but didn't quite capture the magic of the origionals

reviewText: Temper your expectations, and you might enjoy this game. First off, don't think the screenshots on the store page are how it actually looks - I went in thinking it would be a gorgeous dungeon crawler and was severely let down. The game is actually quite hideous, and often looks about ten years too old. Inexplicably, it's also already a frontrunner for the worst optimized game of 2014. It doesn't matter how good your computer is - it will sound like it's about to blast off into space, and the game will chug and chop as you play. It's a shame too, because past all that the game offers quite an enjoyable old-school romp. Gone are the days of free roaming. This is a turn-based first-person RPG on a grid. The story is Fantasy 101, and hardcore fans of the Might and Magic series will probably get more out of it than everyone else. If you're like me, you'll skip the awful NPC dialogue and bash your head against your desk the 100th time your mercenary says, Looks like they smelled us - who forgot to take a bath?" Still
date: there's some definite satisfaction out of exploring the map
hoursPlayed: and encountering enemies that will kill you in one hit (only to come back and faceroll them later on). The game will run around 40 - 60 hours if you want to do all the sidequests. Grab when it's $5 if you're looking for a blast of dungeon-crawling nostalgia - just don't expect it to be a polished or particularly original experience."

reviewText:
I'll preface this by saying this review is indicative of the full game experience (NOT just early access like most of these reviews seem to be for).  I'm a long time Might and Magic fan (yes, that includes the ones before VI!) and from a gameplay standpoint it most certainly delivers.  Here's a quick rundown of the good and bad.

BAD
-The game is saddled with the dreaded UPlay.  The servers are all over the place (not quite Origin levels) which can be a pain or can be painless depending on which way the wind blows.  That also means the game has some unlockables and achievements and the like, but all accessed through the UPlay client.
-The game is buggy as hell.  After several months of 'early access' I expected it to be a little more polished.  It never reaches HOMM6 levels of ridiculousness, and I never had any game-breaking bugs, but there are a lot of graphical glitches and other interesting things that will be seen from even the most powerful machines.
-There seems to be some content either missing and/or unfinished in the final product.  I won't spoil anything here but a look at the UPlay achievements indicates a lot of inaccessible material.
-Enemies do not respawn and there is no 'respec' option, so it is not completely out of the realm of possibility to paint yourself into a corner.

GOOD
-Extremely solid and (mostly) fair turn-based combat.  There are a few too many battles that are initiated with enemies spawning on all sides of you, but once you learn to expect it you can get in to most fights fully buffed.
-Varied party options and a great deal of spells and skills to take advantage of.  As with all RPGs some are *far* more useful than others but once you nail down a balanced team you can start blasting through monsters with gusto.
-Fantastic voice acting and dialogue.  Story sequences are sparse but enjoyable.  The music is also great but sometimes will 'disappear' for long stretches (possibly a bug).
-Lengthy quest and a lot of side material.  Doing all the available quests for a party of 4 different classes and exploring the entire world took around 40+ hours for me.
-Several callbacks to earlier Might and Magic (as well as Heroes of Might and Magic) installments that will make you miss New World Computing.

Overall I very much enjoyed my time with M&MX-Legacy.  Any fans of the early series (1-3 and especially Xeen) will find a lot to like here.  For the rest of you with a passing interest I would advise waiting until either some bug fixes hit or a steam sale to take the plunge.

reviewText:
Good throwback to the grid based Might and Magic games like 3, 4, 5 (Isles of Terra, Clouds of Xeen/Darkside of Xeen).  Not the most well optimized game -- it doesn't look extremely good, but it will *bury* a GTX 580 -- when entering shops, my GPU fan shoots to 100% and the card temp goes to 90-95C.  Fairly widespread issue but no acknowledgement from the vendor on their forums.

In any case, the game is good -- the story is mindless and may as well be non-existant, unfortunately, but the gameplay is pretty much classic MM.  The smaller party size makes things slightly more strategic as your margin of error has decreased notably, which also helps to contribute to an overall greater difficulty level than the previous.

I hope they fix the optimization problems, it's silly that a game that looks like this can load my GPU in ways that Crysis 3 and Far Cry 3 don't, but even if they don't, if you liked the grid / turn based Might and Magic games, this is an easy $25 to spend.

reviewText:
-Rewarding old-school experience-

-First impression-
Starting off completely linear for the beginning hours and in the worst graphic setting regardless of card, MMX makes a terrible first impression but I'm glad I persisted - it improves a lot later (also changed the settings). After the second city the game opens up leaving you to choose which side quest to tackle or which way to go.
-Battles-
Like previous MMs high level enemies may lurk just around a corner and slaughter you so you save/reload a lot while exploring. Even the normal" fights are challenging so if you want to play a cakewalk game this is not for you.
Every battle turn you decide whether your PCs cast healing or an elemental shield or weaken the enemy armor
date:
whether to attack or drink a potion. Also the tiles you stand on play a tactical role as you discover by dying to the second boss (yes you will die). Moving into a position where you get flanked can spell your doom and the harder battles have you flanked from all sides.
-Other Gameplay-
A lot of randomized loot to choose from. No hand-holding like respecing skills or warning if you enter a difficult area beside the "dangerous caves". No big spoilers on the automap or arrows pointing at your quest target.
Bunch of secret loot caches to find
recommended: hidden treasure rooms and powerful relics just like in the past.\nAlso riddle questions
hoursPlayed: switch
voteText: stepping and teleport puzzles and traps. Not always fun but mostly.\nAlong the way you find elemental shards to place on a corresponding altar to trigger a boss fight. This gives you a useful ability like forestwalk
helpfulPercent:
waterwalk or enemy awareness.

PC-wise there are 4 races each with 3 exclusive classes (might/magic/hybrid) = 12 classes and seven schools of magic. You only have 2 male and 2 female portraits per race which is rather lazy. You choose 4 dudes for your party. Depending on class you can either not learn a skill at all or expert/master/grandmaster it like the berserker can master "axe skill" and grand-master "spear skill" but can not learn "sword" or "dagger" or "heavy armor".

-Legacy-
MMX plays unlike the previous MMs
votesHelpful:
mostly feels like Wizardry8 meets Worlds of Xeen. It features a lot of easter eggs like a girl who wants to go to the circus like that Nicolai(?) from MM6 or a poem about the destroyer from MM9. Also characters reappear and the shrines to visit on a certain day. Sadly no insta-death fountains anymore.
I feel it's a worthy entry to the M&M-franchise which appeared all but finished after the ill-received MM9 and frankly I'm glad they're back.

I can recommend this game for fans of complex party-turn-based RPG-games as of old or any RPG-fan who likes a challenge as the game is really entertaining and there is a lot to do and to explore."

reviewText: Fantastic turn-based, grid-based fantasy RPG.  Similar to Legend of Grimrock, but bigger and better in most respects.  Play on the warrior difficulty for a serious, but fair challenge.  There's not a lot of hand-holding -- with riddles, puzzles, and high-level mobs strewn about the continent.  It's an interesting, loot-filled, and occasionally unforgiving dungeon crawler, and I highly recommend it.\n\n
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
As a hardcore M&M series gamer and have finished this game. What this game lacks can be described in one word and that word is grandness. Start with music department. It is relatively weak and as I am writing this, I can't remember any of its melody. Whereas if I am asked to play music from M&M 6 on a piano now. I can do it in a heartbeat and it was more than 16 years ago since I first played M&M 6. Next thing is items. In Legacy, items are represented by small icons inside inventory window. How lame is that. A two-handed axe has the same dimension and takes up the same amount of spaces as an one-handed dagger. It just feels cheap and low quality. Another thing M&M 6 outshines Legacy is  critters. Where are titans, medusas and dragons? You even get to kill angels in previous games. In Legacy, minotaurs are pretty much the only epic monster left. And it is introduced early in the game (Act 2). By the time you reache the end, most of the monsters you are fighting are human like. If I want to kill human, I might as well be playing Battlefield 4.
However, this game has shown some improvements. Improvements like spells. In Legacy, they have removed many useless spells. But dark school magic is still a waste of time once you reach expert level. Battles are not as grand but require more tactic. Map and towns are not huge, if you like sightseeing you may get disapointed. But the good part is that you don't waste too much time travelling around.
Overall, this is a good game. If you are looking for an old school RPG. This is it. If you are a M&M fan looking for something that would blow every M&M game out of water. You may get disappointed. But Legacy is certainly worth a try.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game feels nice. It's a trip back to when games were simple, but that doesn't mean they were easy.

Although you can get a bit lost if you skip dialogs or don't read things throughly, the game do not urge you into action. You have all the time you want to do what you must do (if you stand still haha). You move over squares, take actions upon things in front of you, engage battles, have your way into dungeons.

The game has a good music and also a voice casting and environment sounds which does give life where you go, and also they points out some of the feelings in your crew (like when they get tired and hope for some rest).

Enemies may be easy or tough depending on your approach or care. You might want to have some spells cast in prevention to any enemy engaging you at melee combat, which sadly don't allow your to run away, so you may run while you're engaging enemies in a ranged combat, however you may also get hit if they are in the same line as your are, and, sometimes, you may encounter tough enemies that you might not survive the tale. And that's something I enjoyed. I felt menace with the unknown, fearing a trap anytime soon that could end my history. That way, you don't play carelessly, but you are forced to be cautious and wary, force you to explore everywhere you can reach, before going to more dangerous areas.

I used to play MM VII, which has a very different gameplay, however I liked X also. They are different, but enjoyable all the same. I must say that killing a red dragon at the first map area, in VII, was very entertaining. I still cannot see a way to beat a too strong foe in X with a novice team, given that you are bound to turn-based events. In VII, you could only beat that red dragon in Emeral Island not by using turn-based battle, because then, you could run and dodge his attacks freely, rather than hoping it would miss, which he rarely did.

People might not like much a turn-based first person rpg, but I say you can try it. You'll have your time to adjust yourself to the task, and some rewards are very interesting, you start really enjoying the whole thing and you want to get to the bottom of the problems. Ah, remember to save your potions, right?

I'm still far from the ending, I believe, but I'm not in a rush. I want to experience it slowly and steady.

reviewText:
Requires Uplay, so instead of just Steam running in the background you'll now have ANOTHER DAMN THING running in the background. DO NOT BUY unless you like signing up for stupid bullcrap where they want your email address so they can spam you and sell your information or send you advertising.

Fun if you like to figure out where to go and what to do by trial and death. Save a lot. Reload a lot. There are no respawns, so do your internet research to figure out what your party needs before you go forth, or else you'll be behind the power curve that the game throws at you.

Speaking of internet research, you need to know what quests/areas/subareas to do in what order, or else ...total party kill. There's no way to disengage from combat. You'll die. A lot. Because you didn't do your internet research ahead of time. If this is fun for you, go for it.

Ranged weapons are mostly useless due to the grid system. You'll need to return to town a lot to restock on supplies. Buy tons of mana potions, because there's no mana regen that I can see.

Want to improve your characters? Find the trainers. Run back and forth to town. A LOT. Figure out where the trainers are. YAY SO MUCH FUN. No. It's also grid based, and the texture quality in some notable places is just horri-bad. CHECK OUT THE TOWN NAME ON THE SIGN AS YOU LEAVE THE FIRST TOWN.

lol.

The game has a good music and also a voice casting and environment sounds which does give life where you go, and also they points out some of the feelings in your crew (like when they get tired and hope for some rest).

Enemies may be easy or tough depending on your approach or care. You might want to have some spells cast in prevention to any enemy engaging you at melee combat, which sadly don't allow your to run away, so you may run while you're engaging enemies in a ranged combat, however you may also get hit if they are in the same line as your are, and, sometimes, you may encounter tough enemies that you might not survive the tale. And that's something I enjoyed. I felt menace with the unknown, fearing a trap anytime soon that could end my history. That way, you don't play carelessly, but you are forced to be cautious and wary, force you to explore everywhere you can reach, before going to more dangerous areas.

I used to play MM VII, which has a very different gameplay, however I liked X also. They are different, but enjoyable all the same. I must say that killing a red dragon at the first map area, in VII, was very entertaining. I still cannot see a way to beat a too strong foe in X with a novice team, given that you are bound to turn-based events. In VII, you could only beat that red dragon in Emeral Island not by using turn-based battle, because then, you could run and dodge his attacks freely, rather than hoping it would miss, which he rarely did.

People might not like much a turn-based first person rpg, but I say you can try it. You'll have your time to adjust yourself to the task, and some rewards are very interesting, you start really enjoying the whole thing and you want to get to the bottom of the problems. Ah, remember to save your potions, right?

I'm still far from the ending, I believe, but I'm not in a rush. I want to experience it slowly and steady.

reviewText: If you like turn-based grid-style RPG games, this is a great one to pick up on the cheap. I was able to beat this with a Blademaster, Rune Priest, Druid, and Freemage, and I have watched quite a few win with other combinations, leading me to beieve that you can beat the game with any makeup, provided you spec into their strengths and figure a combat strategy that will keep you alive.

reviewText: Linear, but pretends not to be. While a person has a choice, the static encounters (no respawn) do largely require certain levels/gear. The 'choice' to go where a person wants to go is false and numerous notes must be made to navigate where to go at later points. The game also doesn't display encounter level, making notes taken just reflect 'too hard at level 7' and the such. Being an older gamer I thought I'd enjoy the challenge of a turn-based RPG, but the game is much weaker than Might and Magic games released 10+ years ago. As an added negative, the game should run/load incredibly fast as it does not have fluid movement from AI programmed nasties like a majority of games nowadays; yet the programmers failed miserably and the game loads/lags well beyond what it should (a rough guess would be it runs at 5% of what it should comparing it to other graphically intense newly released games played on the same system with similiar settings. Finally, the game requires Uplay for the final 'gah' (run Steam to run Uplay to run Might and Magic 10).\n\nIf you are immensely bored, find it for 99 cents or less, and a glutton for punishment buy it; otherwise get anything else.

reviewText:
I played mm6 thru mm8. I loved them all.
I like this one very much. It has the feeling of the old ones.

To sum things up:
Pros:
-combat sistem and spells/skills combos to get you thru the fight
-it's big. Compared with the old ones. Usualy the new games you finish them in one day, this one can keep you posted for days.
-mini puzles
-unique items that lvl up with xp
-after killing 7 times a npc you can get all his stats (resists, defence etc)
-the atmosphere
-the dificulty (i;m playing it warrior dificulty- the biggest) is just enough to keep an old school player on his toes.
-the greed to explrore more and more

Cons:
-grid movement it;s getting me sick.
-static NPCs, lacks life
-overall static decor of the map
-interface could be better
-lacks customisation of your characters. 4 pictures and 2 voice types/genre
-frew spells and skills (it could be interesting with more to spice things up)


Overall i like it very much.
If you loved the last MM's, you will love this one to.
If you never played the old ones, start with MM6 and play them all until this one, trust me the graphix does not mather of what this game offeres.

I hope this could help anyopne to decide.

Buy it!

I picked up this game on a discount and I'm quite happy with the purchase. The gameplay really takes me back to the Mandate of Heaven days and filled me with quite a bit of nostalgia.

The pros of the game are that it is very like old Might and Magic with wonderous places to go and fun dungeons to explore. The music is good, the gameplay is good, and I found the game to keep me interested through to the end.

The cons of the game is that the developers have abandoned it after one DLC. I also discovered that the DLC purchase I made for the game on Steam didn't apply once you moved to UPlay where you are required to launch the game from. I still had to spend UPlay points to unlock my DLC.

But at less than five bucks the game was worth a play. Buy it on deep discount and you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
A good old school rpg not without its flaws. First of all, the story and the lore is nothing to write home about in my opinion. Furthermore, I like the grid-based style dungeon crawler but it is really quite strange to use the grid-based movement in an open enviroment. Besides, it is really quite annoyed that you can't move when one enemy is adjacent of you and some other enemies are shooting at you from the distance. There is also some technical problem involving some low FPS that I encounter during somewhere on the world map. Other annoyed little problems including no space to store your items & equipment, obscure puzzle and that you can't scroll the map.

Although the game has some problem, it still has some good old-school fun including challenging combat, nice dungeons full of traps, monsters, treasures and puzzles and finally  the planning and  buidling of your party. If you can stand its rough edges and you enjoy old school rpg, you may find it worthwhile to try this game.

reviewText:
It seems that this game is an attempt to recreate spirit of Might & Magic 3 (year 1991). Sounds quite nice to people (including me) who like M&M 3 or Xeen themed ones (3-5 and Swords of Xeen).

Graphics are quite good, but not spectacular.

The biggest problem for me is that they recreated M&M 3 played on lower end (for 1991) computer. It is not too responsive, actions take too much time. And there was not much difference between highest and lowest graphics settings, so this lethargy was game design decision, not insufficient power of my computer. And to make things worse, there are fewer fast travelling options (no Time Distortion, Teleport or Jump spells; and Lloyd's Beacon" [Spirit Beacon] is not early accessible).

There is no arena too
date: by the way. And no working bank. And no science-fiction elements.\n\nSo
recommended: the game does not look good for either M&M 3-5 or M&M 6-9 fans. Those who did not like M&M 3-9 would not like this one too
hoursPlayed: those who did not play M&M 3-9 would better play them before this game."

reviewText:
It saddens me that this game was frowned upon by gamers. Because it is actually good. For me M&M-X looks like a large priceless ruby with small flaws and dents here and there.

Yes, it has filthy Uplay, but once you set it up it won't bother you much.

Game has minor bugs and glitches, but nothing gamebreaking so far.

It degrades performance after a few hours of gameplay.

It will have slowdowns when you pass through borders between locations with different objects (ex. From Plains to Forest), and poor performance in some locations like magic forest and jungle.

I don't have CtDs, or other stability issues.

Game has beautiful graphics and looks very nice. It also has pretty balanced and satisfying gameplay.

Barks of your characters were poorly done and feels like a result of lazy work.

Puzzles are somewhat easy to solve. Nothing too complex.


I can't remember a single RPG from the past that hadn't some bugs in it. For an example: There were bugs in Ultima 8: Pagan, and in both Ultima Underworld games, but they still were great games because of gameplay.

If you like this gameplay style and look and feel of RPGs from the past, then buy M&M-X on sale for a few bucks like I did. Game deserves to be played alongside with Legend of Grimrock 1 and 2.

The game is well balanced, quite difficult at the beginning, so that you will need to come back later for some bosses, and even in late game, remains challenging. The size of the game is nice, also that there are some riddles and puzzles in the dungeons.\nNegative: Graphics outdated, bad decisions in the beginning (many experts, Masters are not accessible until later acts, as they are located in cities you cant access!), a lot of walking around due to lack of decent teleport system; weak presentation of the story". Last
date: UPLAY does not work properly if game is bought through Steam... you need to contact Support to be able to get UPlay points and unlock Rewards (worked with al other UPlay gmaes I have).\n\nAll in all
recommended: a nice and addicting RPG similar to older MM titles

reviewText: Ahhh, that was a really enjoyable game. I played its older 'sister' and was happy to see the same spirit with immensely better graphics. All the cool stuff from the previous game remains and more interesting elements were added (fun secrets, riddles to stir your brain, etc.) The only minus I found was that some quests can't be finished because they are class-specific, but hey, that makes replayability potential higher :-) Although the plot is straighforward you can just go on exploring the world. I will definitely play it again in the near future and I await further DLC because one (with a bit hard level of difficulty) is just not enough. Uplay as usual is a definite minus for Ubisoft.

reviewText:
It saddens me that this game was frowned upon by gamers. Because it is actually good. For me M&M-X looks like a large priceless ruby with small flaws and dents here and there.

Yes, it has filthy Uplay, but once you set it up it won't bother you much.

Game has minor bugs and glitches, but nothing gamebreaking so far.

It degrades performance after a few hours of gameplay.

It will have slowdowns when you pass through borders between locations with different objects (ex. From Plains to Forest), and poor performance in some locations like magic forest and jungle.

I don't have CtDs, or other stability issues.

Game has beautiful graphics and looks very nice. It also has pretty balanced and satisfying gameplay.

Barks of your characters were poorly done and feels like a result of lazy work.

Puzzles are somewhat easy to solve. Nothing too complex.


I can't remember a single RPG from the past that hadn't some bugs in it. For an example: There were bugs in Ultima 8: Pagan, and in both Ultima Underworld games, but they still were great games because of gameplay.

If you like this gameplay style and look and feel of RPGs from the past, then buy M&M-X on sale for a few bucks like I did. Game deserves to be played alongside with Legend of Grimrock 1 and 2.
