reviewText:
I'm not entirely sure this is a fitting homage to the series, let alone a worthy sequel to the original Might and Magic first person adventure games. This feels more like a Wizardry game than anything, only it does not have random encounters.

If you're looking for an updated version of M&M 6: The Mandate of Heaven, you're going to notice immediately that combat is turn based instead of action based and that you're not able to cheese the ranged attacks quite the same way you did in the last few titles. This forces the element of difficulty into the game that used to come from having to strategize about when and where to cast spells and run from enemies. Once engaged in melee combat, you can't back away or use exits, and very often you're arbitrarily ambushed and beaten down from behind. This leaves little to no strategy available to the player to decide when and where to engage the enemy. Worse still, every skill you need to progress is gated by leveling up multiple times and collecting money, which there is a limited amount of in the game.

This entire game feels like it was designed by people who did not play the original series and do not fully understand the mystique and challenge of M&M adventure games. The elements are there but different. Most of the difficulty in this game comes from needing to block or chug potions at the right time. And you can't even equip the best shields available to you in the first town. You have to complete several incredibly difficult dungeons and make it to the second town before you're even allowed to purchase the training to equip them. This makes the fights with tougher enemies frustrating if not outright unfair. Those who would focus on defense to secure the best outcome are punished while people who choose whatever deals the most damage are rewarded; All in all, this is par for the course for turn based games but not balanced the way M&M 1-6 were. Moreover, entire methods of playing the game, such as going with heavy armor and shields, goes completely unrewarded, so there's no point to that portion of the content. You do not have a front-line and a back-line since enemies can reach any of your party members to attack them at any time, so there isn't even signficant incentive to have defensive members balancing against softer damage dealers until halfway into the game when you actually get usable healing spells. By then, you'd have been better off going full barbarian or mage across the board.

The only genuinely positive part of this experience is that the dungeons and quests all string together nicely like an mmo and it's easy to figure out where to go next just from exploring and poking around on the mini map, talking to people, etc. That and, somehow acknolwedging the limitations of non-respawning chests and enemies, the game apparently dumps loot on you when you find it, so that's nice.

I haven't played a full team of mages like I mentioned earlier yet but I suspect they work much better than the classes I was trying before; And if that is the case, then this is the only great similarity between the original games and this one. Overall, I don't want to take the time to play it anymore after having gotten my butt kicked repeatedly. I'm already too frustrated after a few hours of trudging around in the Lighthouse. The difficulty curve is ridiculous and fights go from being winnable to being totally hopeless, from room to room even. Moreover, there's almost nothing to indicate to you when going in a room or across a bridge will be life threatening so you can never learn from your mistakes. There are even several places you're clearly meant to return to when you're stronger, but how much stronger is somewhere between vaguely incomprehensible and utterly unfathomable. It feels like a big slap in the face when you as a player go in a door that was open to you and can't even escape certain demise because you weren't genuinely going to be allowed an opportunity to succeed at what lay behind it. This kind of high stakes trial-and-error is very unrewarding and disappointing.

Update: I have now played with a full team of mages and it's as I suspected. I was able to get this team to the place of progress it had taken hours to get to before within about 30 minutes. Of course once you run into the one thing that's immune to the school of magic you've been focusing on or up the difficulty from normal to hard, you can expect to be back in the boat of unplayable content and frustration. Overall, the game seems to want to force you to have to bring a specific party to accomplish the goals it sets before you. Some doors can't even be found and some passage ways can't even be opened unless a person with a high score in a specific stat is able to locate and/or open them for your team, which means teams lacking that stat may not even be able to progress in certain dungeons at all. This is very detrimental as, 1) it's impossible to know what the recommended (or required) team composition is upfront and 2) playing with any other party composition is apparently almost futile.

TLDR; This is a competent and somewhat fun to play turn-based RPG but has little to nothing to offer those who are fans of M&M6. I'd still like to recommend this one because it's challenging and a classic first person dungeon crawler like Wizardry, but I can't while it's at any price over 10 dollars. The fact that Wizardry 6 is the same kind of game and was slightly better than this despite having come out 24 years ago prevents me from doing so. If you were hoping to have some fun with this one, buy Wizardry Renaissance and play it all the way through first. Then maybe pick this one up and play it out of boredom when it falls below 10 dollars standard price.

this game gets a bad rap for a few reasons:

-uplay

now if you can get pass those things you will end with a very competent RPG that feels like a mix of a dungeon crawler with exploration that kinda remenbers zelda or metroid,  with a very very good combat system that is totaly worth your time

reviewText:
Best RPG I've played in years, and has quickly become my single favorite game. After playing this I just HAD to play the rest of the M&M series, and I played from 3 to 9 and loved every second of it. This is how RPGs are supposed to be!

Pros:
- awesomely fun RPG game in pretty much every way.

Cons:
- support was unfortunately pulled by Ubisoft before a host of audio problems could be patched out, so we're stuck with them forever now. Battle music gets stuck on all the time, sounds constantly don't play or have wrong volumes. With a long enough play session you can end up with 3+ battle songs all playing at the same time all out of synch, which is pretty irritating to hear. these problems are extremely disappointing since the game itself is otherwise so amazing. exiting and running the game again does fix it though (temporarily).

- After having played the rest of the series, there are a few things in comparison that I miss, but these are not strictly good or bad:

- most M&M games have an accelerating levelling scale. progression is slow in the beginning, but by the end you're gaining like 10 levels per trainer visit. in this one, progression does start slow, and does accelerate at first, but at the end it slows to a crawl, and you end up basically frozen and will never be good at everything you could have been good at. this is pretty strongly different than the other M&Ms where you could master everything about your class and still have tons of points left over. depending on your point of view this could be a good or bad thing.

- this game actually has *better* tactical combat than any of the other M&M games, and depending on which classes you choose, you can still become very powerful. though the classes are actually very imbalanced as well, some being extremely powerful and some being very weak. again, this may or may not be a bad thing.

reviewText:
Such a fun game. If you like the old might & magic games, you'll love this one. It is buggy and I couldn't play it with the highest graphics because some effects will crash the game. I set all to medium or low and I enjoyed the game nontheless.

Some cool riddles, cool but simple puzzles. great intense battles, cool unique items that level up. Really loved this game.

I think that, if they step away from Unity and get an engine that doesn't make your life a living hell, and do more of  the cool things they made for this game, M&M XI should be a return to the old days when M&M was the best turn-based rpg out there.

Would recommend? To a M&M fan sure, buy it now! To a regular rpg gamer, I'd say buy it on sale or look for something else.
